I also loved the cameo's they had and that truck that the old lady drove in the beginning was also from the first film! And if the end made you say, WHAT! Thats It? THATS THE ENDING? Well, if you remember, it is similar to the end of the original Dawn of the Dead. Also, my favorite part was when the guy Andy, the guy in the building across from the mall, is shooting the zombies that look like celebrities! I thought that was funny!I liked all the comedy in this film a lot! Anyway, this movie is good in my book!

title: remake or not to be...
review:
DAWN OF THE DEAD (2004) *1/2 D: Zack Snyder. Sarah Polley, Ving Rhames.

This is a massive "no, no" and should have been called a different name. It was a complete re-imagining of the first masterpiece, and a bit underdone as a remake. Even as a modern day action/horror piece, the violence was plentiful but not as effective. A hint to is why such a bland choice, it lacks the conviction, character building, and suspence that made the iced up original so pulse quickening.

Couldn't put it in any better words myself. It just sucks! Lots of one liners, and lacks charm.

The original film had moments like "Like a charm, like a f***ing charm", "We've got this man, we've got this by the a**", "I see you, chocolate man", "You never aim a gun at anyone mister!... Scary isn't it, isn't it!" And etc, etc....

The mall was a mystery in the original... In the remake, they quieltly walk through the door.

The still born zombie was not effective, just trite.

More like watching a video game than watching a horror movie. The characters were stupified, and lacked a touch of CHARACTER, they were props... Please, change the title to another before it's DVD release. Call it AFTERNOON OF THE DEAD, or DEAD AFTER BREAKFAST, or something so similar to every zombie rip off. I'm about ready to make my own if this keeps up! RUBINSTEIN, HOW COULD YOU!!!!

title: You have to see this film!!!!!!
review: I went into this film not expecting too much from it as the original was utterly crap, cheesy in every sense of the word. However the film took what was a great original concept and made it into the film it was destined to be. When the film began I thought it might spend the first half hour explaining how the zombies came to be, but, I was thrust right into the action about five minutes in. The very first zombie scene in the bedroom had me jumping out my chair at every second, I was astonished. The film manages to keep up it's great suspense and also throw in some great humour without making the film cheesy. I will also give you a tip for when you go to see it, do not leave right after what you think is the ending as the credits roll the real ending comes alive on the screen which I found to complete the film as the first ending was a bit too cliched and the proper ending left me wondering. Not only does it outclass the original in every way but it's also excellent as a stand-alone film. Everyone MUST see this film!!!!

title: ruining a classic
review: the first time i ever got to see the original Dawn of the Dead i was 7 years old, and i absolutely loved it. the entire Dead trilogy have been some of my favourite horror films ever since. so as the remake was released not long before my 18th birthday i decided what the hell i'll go see it. i already knew that the director was probably going to make a hash of it but i was open minded and thought "well, maybe it won't be so bad" boy was i wrong. i know that ever since us Brit's produced 28 Days Later plenty of people (Brit's as well as Americans- i'm not going to say its only Americans) have said "ooo cool zombie film" if anyone paid attention 28 Days Later was not a zombie film. the whole basis of that film was that scientists had developed a virus that induced incredible rage, it did NOT turn anyone into zombies! i can understand the mistake there but when someone produces a remake of possibly one of the first zombie films, a film that set every rule about zombies, and then screws with all of the rules, i find myself unforgiving. for one thing the originals never meant to make the zombies scary, our reaction was meant to be the scary thing. we couldn't do anything to save ourselves, by the time we understood what they were we had to battle with our own beliefs and societies restrictions, and by that time we were doomed and overrun. the real thing that would destroy us would be ourselves not the undead. also any zombie film fan will know that zombies have two certain characteristics that the new director seems to forget completely. for a start zombies are slow moving creatures due to rigor mortis and muscle deteriation... second zombies work on pure instinct and eat due to instinct, they need to sustenance and aren't well known as picky eaters if its alive, moving and has meat on it, generally they'll eat it.. that includes dogs!!! in fact in several earlier zombie films there were in fact zombie dogs... i remember one character in the remake describing them as zombies when they are clearly not, if anyone recalls the news reports in the original film "they are not cannibals... they feed only on living flesh" a cannibal by definition must feed on its own kind, zombies don't feed on zombies. for those modern horror fans, those who are too young to remember how many wonderfully written and filmed horror b-movies there were in the 80's and prior to that you really should start watching older horror films, because personally i haven't seen a horror film in a long time that has managed to scare me and the last one that did was filmed over a decade ago. the problem with modern horror directors is that they have no concept of subtlety, you can't go for the scares every single second. which is another failing with the new film. making things jump out of nowhere, making characters so irritating that you know they'll be the ones who don't survive. for example in night of the living dead, possibly on of the best horror films i have seen to date (and i have seen most if not all) the sudden change of camera angle to the stuffed heads makes you jump and then laugh at yourself. thats how you direct a scary film.. scare, laugh, calm, laugh, cry, calm and then scare again. you don't under any circumstance scare continuously, as by the third scare the audience is bored and can see it coming "oh no a hand grabbed that guy, phew its just his mate.. argh! a zombie at the door!" doesn't really make for a good film... personally i think the only thing that saved the film even partly was a 30second appearance by the actor who played peter in the original so that he could say the line he made famous to begin with! a line they used as the tag for this film... in my opinion this film was a waste of time and money (¬£11.10 of it not to mention the amount the studio must've fed into this sad excuse for a film) and other than the 30 seconds i just mentioned i wish i could have that time and money back! perhaps next time i'll try to remember that modern horror films will never do justice to their predecessors.

title: Amazing! (Contains mild spoilers)
review:
WOW!

That movie just kicked butt. Every little thing meant something; after Luta got bit, I actually asked my friend if the baby would be a zombie as well, and low and behold-- I saw it. I couldnt love this movie more! It preyed on my most elementry fears-- I fell in love with the characters only to watch them die! And it ROCKED! In the begining, when there were these disaster shots, I was just enthralled. It really amped me for the rest of the movie!! Im totally buying the DVD. I liked it much better then The Ring or those type of films. there was NO stopping the zombies, man. All you have to do in other films is not watch the tape or kill the guy wearing the hockey mask. This one had me scared restless for many days after. Great movie! I reccomend it totally! My closing note:

Nothing rocks more then Zombies with super human abilities eating everyone. Nothing.

title: Best horror movie in a decade?
review:
I was aware that I might be disappointed with Snyder's movie, but I have to say that it really surprised and shocked me. The energy of the movie is quite extreme as is the action. It is a miracle how this major passed German censorship, they are usually quite fast to turn down violence, but none of it here. I liked everything about this movie, especially the movie's credits and the fast running zombies, or the ending. I think the gory content is extreme for a major movie. Will watch this one at least once more.

A big Hello and thanks a lot to Mr Snyder from me and all of my friends!

10/10

title: the credits: they make this film
review:
I haven't seen the original and I'm really interested to see what is original story and what is a new 'twist'

I'm definitely not a horror fan, I was dragged by my dad who was threatening to make me go and see 'the passion of the Christ' and zombies suddenly seemed to be an exciting subject!

The film itself was pretty good, I was quite impressed but then I'd gone in fearing I'd miss the whole film hiding under my coat so.... The only majorly gruesome up close zombieness occurs in the first few scenes, and yes it was gross and perhaps a little unnecessarily so, but it's horror, you expect that. Once they get to the mall though it's more of a thriller/horror and I wound up really getting into it, empathising with characters and cheering zombie deaths, and consequently saying 'no no for gods sake just stab them in the head!'

My second favourite bit is all the stuff on the roof between the people in the mall and Andy across the street. A classic moment is made when they try to get Andy to shoot Jay Leno in zombie form, it's a beautiful moment!

But the film is made by it's credits, don't leave before them and mock those that do because the film goes up about 3 point in my ratings of it by the credits, I won't spoil it for you, just tell you to watch them.

title: My First Zombie Movie!
review: Dawn of the Dead is the very first zombie movie I've seen (if you don't count 28 Days. I enjoyed it very much! I've seen tons of horror movies, and I've learned not to expect anything from them. Just enjoy them! I definetly did! This movie had a few good scares, and even some good laughs. It also had a bright, fun, cast. Sarah Polley is particularly captivating. Though she's not exactly beautiful, something about her makes her very watchable. A great, fun horror movie definitely worth a viewing or two! Watch with loads of popcorn and the lights out! 9/10. Okay, this needs to be ten lines. My reviews are never ten lines, no matter how much I type. Filling Space. Filling Space. Filling Space. Is this ten lines? It looks like ten lines! I hope it will be.

title: what an amazing surprise!
review:
i really enjoyed this film. i'm a big fan of the original (and can't wait for the big oversized dvd set coming out towards the end of summer) and i enjoyed this rethinking of the basic premise of it a hell of a lot. great ensemble cast, innovative direction and killer musical cues. (johnny cash and the vegas lounge version of down with the sickness were friggin inspired) i sure hope the longer form dvd gives us a bit more on the character side, cause these people were far from 1 dimensional and i want to learn more about them all. favorite scene was the overhead helicopter shot of sarah fleeing in her car and the surprise event that happens right in front of her on the highway, it was the money shot that ended a 10 minute roller coaster ride that was the beginning of the movie.

(SPOILER)- man i hope they got away from those undead b**tards on that island, we never technically saw them killed, so i suppose there is a slim chance they managed to get away. i want twighlight of the dead from the same people responsible for this film, i want ving and sarah and the kids, and i want it sooner rather than later. this was a fun flick!

title: Gnarly!
review:
George A Romero's classic Dawn of the Dead is given 21st Century treatment in this cracking gore-fest from first time director Zack Snyder.

Hordes of zombies go on the rampage throughout Middle America, and a group of humans manage to hole themselves up in an abandoned shopping mall to avoid becoming zombie-fodder.

I was a bit sceptical about going to see this as zombie-movies aren't my cup of tea at all. However, see it I did (without a previous viewing of the original) and thoroughly enjoyed it. What makes my opinion of the remake stronger is the fact that the original was on TV a few days later!

Within the first ten minutes you're given a general idea of what's going on, as the carnage and chaos spreads like wildfire around the city. Pretty soon your reward for paying your ¬£5 or whatever is the gore: lots of it! Oh yeah, and the action.

The remake has far more characters in it than the original (something like fifteen, compared to four). As is usual in Hollywood horror movies, the number of characters in them means that predictably they will fall prey to the hordes of nasties running around the mall. Who they will be isn't quite as predictable.

The remake is fast-paced and never boring, while the original dragged on and doesn't really go anywhere for a long time. Also, the remake features zombies more along the lines of those in 28 Days Later, which aren't the shuffling, moaning, brain-chomping beasts they once were: they're faster, stronger and slightly more scary! Plus, these new `Mk2' zombies (with new go-faster stripes!) are much more threatening and they make the film more suspenseful. I know there is a reason for Romero's creatures to be slow and shuffling, but hoorah for the steroid-enhanced undead!

While the original went on into showing the characters holing themselves up in the mall for the foreseeable future, the remake has them wanting to bust out and find civilization again. OK, so some of the acting's not great, there are a ton of clich√©s in there and the music is pretty standard fare for a horror movie (although I do love the Richard Cheese version of Disturbed's `Down With The Sickness', the original version of which chimes in at the end. At least you can now hear what they're singing!).

The movie is definitely not for the faint-hearted, as the gore comes thick and fast with brains a-splattering all over the place! And an over-enthusiastic human with a chainsaw makes for some unintended hilarity as the humans escape the zombie hordes (believe me, it IS funny! Practically the whole cinema was laughing!).

Four outta five stars - and definitely worth viewing is the spoof horror "Shaun of the Dead"!

title: It scared me !!
review:
Good movie. Not the best but a enough to make me jump on my seat often enough. I think it's impossible to compare it to Romero's Dawn of the dead because his version and the new one fall in different categories.

It had to be more visual and have more plots because at the time, you didn't have that Surround Sound and state of the art FX. As most movies today, the sound as become important, more important sometimes than the dialogue. That would explain the many close ups of gun firing, door slamming, bombing, sounds of vehicles moving and other noises necessary to exploit the surround sound effects. Of course the plot is basic in many ways and is surely not very original but does not take away the claustrophobic effect and the fear among the protagonists. The main purpose of the movie is to scare us (mostly by sounds and surprising close ups) and it does right thru the end, as long as you play along with the characters and not spend your time thinking about the Romera version. One advice : don't leave the theater BEFORE the end of the credits.

title: Great!
review:
I had great expectations - and I was not disappointed!

More than just another remake of a classic picture. Very good special effects and a brilliant makeup makes the horror real. New ideas (the running zombies are now a real danger for all of our heroes) and a "new" plot with new characters! A very thrilling picture with black humor and bloody gore elements... I love it!!! My conclusion: Some people say, that you can¬¥t call it a real remake of die original "Dawn...", because there are too much differences between the plots. But if there would be too much accordances, most of the people would say: "No new ideas! Why did they realize this movie? ... waste!" In my opinion it is one of the best remakes ever made!

title: A worthy remake
review: Solid remake of the classic 1978 movie. A much better ending,more humor at the unlikest places elevate this movie to a higher level. The cast is so much more stronger and where has Jake Weber been? He stole this movie as "Michael". My biggest complaint is that zombies running was so 28 Days Later. Zombies don't run,they shuffle. It builds up the tension so more effectively..but other then that,this movie was very creepy! A very good story on the making of this movie can be found at Starlog,a sci-fi magazine. Thats all for now! chow!

title: One Kick Ass Zombie Movie!
review:
Enthralling, Enjoyable, Scary, Suspencful and Humerous all great words to describe DOTD 2004. I cant say I was a fan of the origional, while the premise was fine the execution was poor. But thats enough comparation as the director himself said this is not a scene for scene remake its a completely different movie. And I would have to agree, aside from the zombies and the mall there is nothing else linking this to the origional.

The Film itself top notch, It keeps your attention from the beginning and dosnt let go until the end of the credits (DO NOT LEAVE THE CINEMA OR STOP THE FILM UNTIL THE CREDITS HAVE FINISHED!). The acting is also first class. Ving Rames Shows shows how underused her has been in the Mission Impossible movies (Something that will hopefully be set right in MI:3). While the rest of the actors put in an equally convincing performance.

The Special Effects both Physical and CG are fantastic and beyond what I thought would have been possible on such a low budget movie.

I cannot fault this movie in any way as hard as I try.

9/10

title: Rollercoaster ride
review: I think some of the contributors are a little pretentious to say the least. The original film is one of my all time favourites and after reading the Director's/Cast's comments i have to agree that the new "Dawn" cannot be compared to the 1978 classic as it is a new take on the storyline. The original is a great film because of its low budget and therefore much of the two hours 30 minutes running time time is spent on character development rather than action scenes.This also helps as more time was spent shooting empty mall scenes which gives the viewer a sense of isolation. And after all where the original grabs the imagination is that everyone would like to have an empty shopping mall to help themselves to whatever they liked from the shops therein. At one hours less running time the new "Dawn" is a very good thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat.It is one of the best movies i have seen in a while and unless original "Dawn" fans take it in its own right then i am afraid they will be critical. The opening 30 minutes of society breaking down , including excellent ariel shots of the mayhem below are excellent and set the tone. It is a must see and the only critiscism i can have is it seems a bit crammed. Better editing and maybe an extra 30 minutes running time could have made it even better.

title: Excellent zombie film when it isn't compared to the original
review:
I went to see 'Dawn of the Dead' in the theaters even though the original masterpiece by George Romero is my favorite zombie movie of all time. I had to say I was more than pleased with the overall product, sure the plot flatlines when compared to Romero's satirical script from the original film, but this one delivers in all accounts. The gore is there, even though it isnt as hardcore as the original's but this film is rated R. The zombie action is there and it hits hard!!, also the characters had such a cool chemistry that I really cared for more than one of them.

I have to say that this is an excellent zombie film, and it works on every level. Of course, the title 'Dawn of the Dead' makes a lot of people compare it to the original film, I don't blame them at all. I just didn't care for the connection with the original masterpiece. Remake or not, this film delivered.

title: A Let Down
review:
I usually don't see movies like this... I usually don't see horror movies period. This was an exception because a certain magazine gave it an A and my local newspaper gave it a B. So maybe my mistake was having too high hopes for this one.

According to the reviews, it was witty. Really, it was? Because I must have totally missed the witty part. Even that sarcastic guy who shows up was disappointing. I was expecting humorous comments. Didn't get 'em. The funniest part to me was when Ana was driving away and we get a bird's eye view of the town after the outbreak, and this car comes full speed, misses her Toyota by a few feet and slams into the gas station. It's not like I was looking for 'Frasier' quality intelligence here.

It was also supposed to be scary. Nope. I jumped a couple of times, but that's really it. Gory movies are often mistaken for scary ones.

The acting was... sub par at best. Where was the character development? Ving Rhames is always angry. Sarcastic guy is always... cynical. And Sarah Polley is always willing to rise to occasion, as well as that guy Michael.

All in all, 5/10.

title: Should DOTD 2004 even be called a remake?
review:
Do you think this film could be even called a 'remake'? I saw the original again a few days before seeing Dawn of the Dead 2004, and the only similarity between them seemed to be the mall. Unless I've missed something. I don't think the two films should be compared, or that people should argue which one was better... because they're both entirely different.

Maybe the makers of DOTD 2004 only used the same name because they didn't to be later accused of plagiarism, after people saw that it took place in a mall?

Anyone have any thoughts?

title: Pretty good
review:
I watched this one on a press preview and thought it was quite good. Though fun is a more appropriate word than good cause surely this is no oscar material. I can't remember anything of the original so I wasn't bothered with comparison all of the time.

What I liked best is the fact that it didn't give any stupid explanations for the virus. It's just a nice mix of action, gore and comedy and it has no customary beginning or ending. Works perfect for watching with friends cuz there's no real plot to follow.

Fans of Romero might be offended by this, but like I said, I don't remember the original so I wouldn't know.

title: F***ing Nursery School
review:
When there's no more room in hell, Hollywood will remake a classic...completely void of any intelligence and hardly capable of any creativity. This film relies solely on chase scenes and...well...chase scenes. This "re-imagining" of the superior 1978 classic DAWN OF THE DEAD is nothing but cheap in its mindless pursuit of thrills and chills.

The ultimate flaw of this film is that it does not even care to treat the zombie plague as anything more than a device to have characters flee in fear. The film completely ignores the zombie genre tradition and instead goes the route of obviously ripping-off the successful 28 DAYS LATER by making the infected run and scream. That film at least took the zombie genre and completely reinvented it - creating an all new experience. This film makes no such advancements.

I'm sorry for the harsh review. If you do not want analytical criticisms of your picture, then do not take the title of the ultimate zombie film. That picture is after all best known for its strides in atmosphere, character developments, and political/social satire - none of which appear in this remake. In all fairness, hardly any similarities exist between these two pictures. That's a good thing because I actually feel that I would hate this film more if it tried to emulate the original masterpiece (much like 2003's TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE remake).

If this is a different film, then why work from the original 1978 George Romero screenplay and retain that title? The only reason would be name recognition to make some cash (and of course to wound longtime horror loyalists). Why did they have to tarnish the original's name?

Another serious problem with this film is its total lack of coherency. The whole film was littered with moments of inconsistency. It is almost as if the filmmakers pondered : how can we have this group escape a barricaded shop with their only exit (one door) completely swarmed by zombies? Hmm, I've got it! Let's just use a cutaway and then when we come back to the survivors they are already outside and running. Perfect! Let's just edit their way out of trouble!

How do they gain entrance into the mall when its completely sealed and `shatterproof?' Let's just cutaway to an interior department store window shattering and have the characters just stroll on in. Brilliant! No explanation of how they got in or how zombies aren't entering the same way. Who cares about logic? Let's just show people running and swing the camera around a lot.

Seriously though, the filmmakers did fail at nearly every aspect of this picture but there are two notable exceptions: the pregnancy/birth scene and the armored vans/chainsaw escape.

First, the pregnancy/birth scene. All right, this was very provocative on a number of levels. Not only was it original, but also very compelling from a dramatic/analytical standpoint. It was not done for a mere weird/disturbing scare. The scene was a great moment for the characters involved (it really built Mekhi Phifer's role) but it was also a statement on human nature given the abysmal events of this particular apocalypse. Really moving. Without a doubt - this was the highlight of the script. Furthermore, this will most likely go into zombie movie history along with Lucio Fulci's zombie vs shark moment (1979's ZOMBIE) and Peter Jackson's zombie sex scene (1992's DEAD ALIVE) - which also spawned an offspring. This moment is the film's only contribution to the genre.

Second, the armored vans escape plan (and the subsequent use of chainsaws) was a logical and brilliant move by the screenwriter. An absolute pleasure for those horror fans more suited toward the PHANTASM and EVIL DEAD sequels.

Not a highlight of the film, but definitely a pleasure all its own was the brief appearance of Matt Frewer. I almost expected his last words to be a digital stutter - for those of us who remember his MAX HEADROOM days.

There are also a few cameos (from the cast of the original) scattered throughout the film, but it provides only a second or two of satisfaction for fans. A Tom Savini cameo cannot save a picture (case in point - 2001's CHILDREN OF THE LIVING DEAD) no matter how cool it might be.

Bottom line : the picture is a brainless blockbuster/michael bay venture that will undoubtedly be eaten up by the mindless masses of America. Some may be happy that the zombie genre is back, but its back in the worst way. Grade D-.

title: enjoying things for what they are...
review:
i have been a long time romero fan, as well as a fan of horror genre in general. it is rather unfortunate that the genre rarely produces films that can make the hair on the back of your neck stand up...realistic fiction is usually scarier ie; se7en, requiem for a dream, kalifornia, henry, portrait of a serial killer etc etc etc...

that said, i was extremely excited when i saw the first trailers for dotd2004...when i was a little kid, my dad took me to see the original, and i had nightmares for a month solid. of course i own the original and i have viewed it many many times. what i find so satisfying about the "re-make" is that it doesn't try to be exactly what the original was at all. it is a creative re-telling of the story, taking liberties and paying homage simultaneously. the shot-for-shot remake of psycho, for example, is a complete failure.

knowing the budget limitations of romero's original film, it is brilliant, i dont know why so many people think that it is such a huge social commentary about consumerism. yes, the concept is there, but i think so many are trying to recontextualize his 1978 film and look at it in terms of where film making has gone since then. it's a HORROR movie!!!

dotd2004 is, as well. it is enjoyable, a fun ride, and hopefully it will lead to a day of the dead "re-make" as well as romero's as yet un-made 4th and final installment in the zombie series which so far, 2 studios have promised money for, then rescinded the offers.

to those who hated this film, perhaps you were going in expecting much more than this genre usually delivers, or wanting an exact replica of the original. it is what it is, and i feel that both films can co-exist, albeit, as tomes of their respective eras and budgets. for people who are skeptics going in, i have one word of advice before you see ANY film, MATINEE.

title: possible spoilers
review:
Greetings! There MAY be SPOILERS!!!!

First off I want to say that anybody who sees this movie and wants a Romero-esque zombie flick should rent something by ROMERO! I believe that Romero is a Godfather among horror movies. He IS THE MAN when it comes to zombie flicks. I also think that other films have captured zombie lightning (28 days later, Return of the Living Dead, etc...) but have not re-capitalized on the success of George. With that said I will get to the goods. This is not your fathers zombie movie. The slow shambling dead are gone and replaced by scary sprinters with bad attitudes. These zombies appear to be dead and not just painted a bluish-tint. The makeup is incredible and the film-making is polished more than your average horror movie. Sure there are some plot points that don't add up but who cares? If you can watch this and forget all about Romero and the name on the movie poster you will love this movie. If you go into it and think "That didn't happen in the original" you'll probably hate it. There was a comment about why they named it "dawn of the dead" and I partly agree with the fact they could have named it "Dial Z for Zombie" and it still would have been an effective horror movie, but, it wouldn't have had the big fan base wanting to see it and it wouldn't have had the name recognition that made it able to beat "Passion". I wouldn't recommend letting your kids see this because it is pretty gory and has brief nudity and millions of scary zombies. If my sons would have seen this they would have been sleeping with me until they turned 18. In conclusion, I think any fan of zombie horror will enjoy this movie oodles and oodles. If you liked 28 days later you will surely like this movie. regards, Matt

title: Look mum I'm a Zombie....
review:
I was a bit sceptical about this when I first heard about it as remakes are usually something that I look down upon as I feel they are just aimed at the mainstream critters who have never heard of the original and they are a good cash in for the director and cast as they are digging up old material and adding there flavour to it to make some kind of improvement over the original.

Never the less despite Hollywood's absorbent cash in I was pleasantly surprised and entertained by the whole ordeal. This movie gets straight to the point and lets the zombie carnations out to play within the first five minutes of the film. One thing however, what's with all the fast zombies in movies at the moment? i.e. 28 days later, Chill out a bit will ya, what's wrong with sticking to traditions, zombies are slow, like a snail...a handicapped snail infact.

Ving Rhames as a cop? Not so sure about that. I liked Michael Kelly's character development as CJ and Sarah Polley (Ana) as the star of the show is very convincing here, it was also good to see Tom Savini making a nice little cameo here.

The ending could trouble some people but I felt that it was a fair establishment. Many will have natural hate in there blood at the thought of a remake of Romero's classic, naturally the film doesn't beat the original but compared to many modern day remakes I'll let this one off, now sleep my friends sleep.

title: I've never been so bored during a movie!
review: I would just like to say this was one of the worst films I have ever seen. At least in the past few years. I can take a campy horror film here and there, but they didn't even try. It was so bad, I had trouble not walking out. The only reason I stayed was the hope that I would get to see these annoying characters die! In any film, you must care for at least ONE CHARACTER!  This was just full of lame, unfunny, hidious people and I don't mean the zombies. They should have called it "Dawn of the Cliche"

title: it's really a s**t
review:
I'm really sad to read so many enthusiastic comments for one of the most horrible movies, remakes or whatever you want I've ever seen. It's really sad to consider that times are changin' so quickly that nobody remembers WHY Romero's DOTD is a powerful masterpiece and this remake no more than a little shit. Living dead are a serious thing. And filming a horror movie doesn't mean to use the camera as an MTV employer. I think we're clip- addicted, and the majors know that and go on throwing us this stuff for a quick meal- really better flesh then! Seems too serious as a comment? Romero's movie was especially a great critic to the consumistic society, more than a horror movie. This sort of joke doesn't have a gram of it, it's just a stupid empty box with a f**king nothing inside. I won't talk about the soundtrack, the acting and the pathetic end credits because I'm a good guy, in the end, and I don't want to walk on the dead :-)

0/10

title: worthy remake
review: as a fan of the original, i was pleased...i wasn't sure what to expect, but it was both entertaining and scary...it took the "28 days later" approach combined with the Romero version of "turning" into a zombie...i liked that...it was also the only flick i've seen that a zombie does a certain thing...and i've seen a few zombie flicks in my day...it was more of a homage than a remake...the mall setting, but even that was different...the dialog was snappy and the directing was definetly decent for someone who, i guess from what i know, directed commercials before this...disturbed's "down with sickness" was a fit well...it won't win any oscars, but, on the popcorn scale...10 for me.

title: still thrilling . . . i've seen it again!
review: Oh yeah.  The suped up busses were from romero's idea for dead reckoning. Anyway, we're at such a loss with this movie, really.  Look, in the Dead '78, the humans found the mall--it had everything they could ever want, ever imagine ever having.  Roger, Peter, Steve, Fran became so over-satiated that they wound up becoming dead from within, dead to themselves (even more aparent in the 142 minute version).  Here, like i read somewhere else, the zombies never enter the mall--until the 3rd quarter of the movie and not because of a "former instinct to be in a place once important to them" it was simply to get the humans, i still can't remember their names, I think there's Mike, Ana, Luda, Ken, Andy, CJ.  but that's as much as i can remember even after the second viewing--the character's are not as descript. Dead '78 was a film lambasting the excesses of consumerisim and the gluttony it encouraged.  Dead '04 is taking a pro-consumer stance, almost blaspheming the philosophy of its paradigm (Dead '78).  because look, its rated-R, its fast-paced, almost demanding repeated viewings, its in 2:35.1 aspect ratio enabling universal to market at least 4 dvd versions:  a full-screen r-version, a full-screen unrated version, a widescreen r-version, a wide-screen unrated version, not taking into consideration a "renegade director's cut" possiblility.  There are over 100 dvds on my shelf in my room upstairs.  I'm a consumer.  Universal Studios with its Dead '04 wants me to buy four more dvds to fullyt experience Zach Synder's DAWN OF THE DEAD. At least it was still thrilling the second time around!  It made its money: where's the sequel!!!?  I'm flesh-hungry for more!

title: Extreme Entertainment
review:
Not a good script, not very good acting, action scenes weren't that good either, bad dialog, some of the zombies looked kinda fake and the music is pretty much the standard for any horror movie. I would compare it to Eight Legged Freaks in many ways.

Your average type horror/action movie with a few really disgusting scenes, babies and obese women... But atleast its better then the original in every way possible.

Oh yeah, did I mention I enjoyed it profusely?

9/10

Why does my review have to be 10 lines atleast? I don't need 10 lines for this one, theres not that much to tell really, just an enjoyable movie. I like movies about giant disasters with only few survivers. Stephen King's The Stand is probably my favourite...happy easter everyone

title: Yawn of the Dead
review:
oh dear, oh dear, oh dear...

this movie started off pretty good. the pre-opening titles scenes were great and really built up the old anticipation levels. the title sequence itself was rubbish - Johnny Cash for christ sakes !?! after that it got rubbish very quickly. at about the appearance of "stereotypical shaved-headed black guy no. 2", i realised that in fact this was going to be a cliched, MTV-generation non-event movie after all. damn shame too. the scariest thing about this movie? Tom Savini - he looks EXACTLY the same as he did in the original DotD. that's 25 years old - is Tom actually undead or something? Last word - the soundtrack is absolutely pitiful. some really poor tracks were layered over this movie. WHY !?!?!?! please, please, please, when in another 25 years someone makes another remake of this film, can they put some effort into it and make it GOOD !?!

title: FINALLY, A DECENT ZOMBIE TRIBUTE
review:
Being a horror fanatic isn't easy, nor is to be a zombie-manic because, let's face it, we had been drag to a cinema lounge or to a VHS tape (OK, OK to a DVD disc too!) by taglines and posters which hide a bad plot, remake or sequel. We, zombie-movies fans, face sometimes bad acting, weak plots, terrible make-up / effects, in few words, things that might make one trow-up (and, sadly not for a gore scene!) and /or demanding at the box office your money and that hour and half of your life back. But luckly (at last!) this movie is not of that kind. I haven't seen its 1978 version and I'm so looking forward to it, but this is a pretty well done remake. Naturally being such it has some gaps (hey, nobody is perfect) but what is portrayed on the screen worth it. The first 12-15 mins. and opening credits gives you a pretty good idea for what is to come (actually what is expected of a good horror movie): cool make-up and effects, grotesque action scene full with gore, some jumping moments and, of course, sex! No wonder why its R rated, you are warn even when you log on the web site, sadly most teen boys aren't allowed to buy a ticket and watch it if they aren't in the company of an adult (which teen on its 5 senses would go with his /her parents to the movies? this one in particular!) Sorry guys those are the rules but believe me people there is a reason for such!

So if you are a great fan of the genre who wants to watch a pretty scary and grotesque film just for the sake of fun go, but I must stress that you should think twice if you are weak of heart or just eat a meal before.

Have fun and fasten your belts, BELIEVE ME!!!

title: ******GREAT******
review: This is what a remake is supposed to be, Can't find one flaw with this movie. 10 out of 10. This will not be the last of Zack Snyder, he has talent. A must see for everyone. To bad he couldn't have directed The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. The first 10 minutes alone are better than many movies I have seen in the past 5 years alone. actually you never even get a chance to take a break from the start of the movie it's like a 100 min rollercoaster ride that doesn't stop. I was a trying to be open minded going in the theater since I was some what disappointed in Texas, but once Dawn started I knew that this was going to satisfy my zombie hankering. It's been a while since we've had a really good zombie flick, really to long. romero should be pleased he is the master but it is nice to see other film makers respect his work. He should be proud!

title: Remakes can be good. Who'd of thought?
review: One enamole that has seemed to escape the foray of modern cinema is the fact that someone could take an already magnificently executed plot and put the just right spin on it as not to come off as redundant.  You'd think with all the talented directors in Hollywood this would've happened by shear hit and miss before 2004.  But nonetheless, the art of film remaking takes a well-waited turn for the best in "Dawn of the Dead".  No doubt inferior than the original, (Just saying otherwise would have me condemend to the fiery depths of Movie hell with the likes of "Fast and the Furious", and "Freddy Got Fingered".) this film does stack up well next to Romero's ingenius 1978 opus of the same name.  It rivals it if you will.  This in my opinion is mainly in part of the fact that it's more or less it's own stand alone movie.  Save for the occasional exception or in-joke.  I mean when Ken Foree made his cameo and repeated his famous line from the original I literally jumped in my seat and almost wet myself. The people around me stared at me and presumaby made mental retardation jokes at me later thus destroying my faith in the movie going public but that's neither here nor there.  Anyway the bottom line is with a great remake like this finally gracing our presence the catch-22 of the whole ordeal is this will simply inspire more Hollywood remakes.  I find "Based on a screenplay..." to be one of those long lost credits becoming trendy again.  Well it could be worse.  They could remake "Walking Tall"   (Hah, ha, Well I gues I walked into that one)

title: Not Bad!
review:
Probably the best remake of a horror film ever to grace the big screen. Loved the beginning, I even got the sense they did actually try to start off from the remake of Night of the Living Dead over ten years ago here.

Obviously this is a remake of the original but it isn't. 'What?' you must be thinking. It has the same concepts using the Mall etc, but it does have the right to be its own film. There are a lot of new characters, new stories and it is not an exact remake of the original. After the first three minutes of the film its mainly all out action with a slow 15-20 minutes in the middle where they added a little humour which I enjoyed. The Burt Reynolds part was brilliant. Thought they could have done more with the baby. They could have at least had the little blighter bite somebody. There are a lot of positives here for the hardcore horror fans. We have a decent enough script, decent acting, decent zombies and a lot of gore factor. The chainsaw parts are very good. Go into watching the film expecting a lot of fun and thats what you will get back in return. No real scary bits to mention unless you are pregnant.

8/10

title: More of a new movie than a remake
review:
I'm a great fan of the Romero films, and own all 3 on DVD. I'm also waiting excitedly to buy the latest DOTD on DVD after having seen it at the cinema.

The first film is utterly different to the 'remake'. So different that it will be like owning two complimentary zombie films in my DVD collection, and it definitely won't be (and hasn't been) a case of being unable to view the old film after watching the second.

DOTD 2004 is an outstanding action film, with some good horror elements, and suspense, where as DOTD 1978 is more subtle and atmospheric, and more concerned with clever social satire, than with out-and-out gungho action. The latest film is a white knuckle ride like no other, but the earlier film stays in your mind long after the movie has ended, with many disturbing issues left for the viewer to mull over.

I don't think that DOTD 2004 is quite as successful as the first film in its portrayal of dead people coming back AS dead ghouls. I was reminded of films like 'The Exorcist' and '28 Days Later' when ever a DOTD 2004 zombie was leaping about maniacally on the screen....almost as if they were possessed by raging demons or in the throes of a viral contagion/ madness. Romero's zombies looked as if they really were dead bodies reanimated, with the lack of mobility you'd expect from a corpse that has suffered brain death and physical decay/ trauma. DOTD 2004 zombies seemed too 'fit' and capable of Olympian feats of agility and speed that were probably beyond the living person they'd replaced. Although it made for visceral hair-raising chase scenes it also added a level of implausibility to an already implausible premise.

It also shows how Romero's version didn't have to 'hide' behind the easier plot device of how the world was taken over by what amount to (in DOTD 2004) unstoppable foes with immense strength and savagery. In the remake, mankind really has no chance to win/ survive. The zombies are as strong/ fast as them, they outnumber them...they never sleep, have no moral compunctions to inhibit their actions. It's almost a no-brainer that everyone is going to die. In Romero's film you have slow zombies that only really succeed in vast numbers, but which can be contained if the living coordinate their attacks and help each other survive...Which is where the main difference in the films arises.

Romero points the finger at how ridiculous our conflicting morals are. We're avid shallow materialistic shoppers, yet cannot bring ourselves to kill/ dispose of potentially lethal corpses even when our very survival is at stake. The bikers are thoughtless anarchists who could have shared the mall with the holed-up survivors, but instead waste a golden opportunity, and even more precious lives, due to greed. But Snyder basically says 'there's this virus, so now there's all these superfast zombies, and hey, you're all going to die.'

But it's scary. No doubt about it. Romero gives you scares laced with the frustration that the apocalypse could have been avoided if only we'd united and nipped it in the bud at its outset. Snyder gives us the horrid realisation that his vision of the virus would absolutely catch us unprepared and leave the living with virtually no hope, almost over night.

The film's opening gets the enormity of the cataclysm across better than any zombie film before it. The first 9 minutes and the following credits are an absolute miracle of cinema, and deliver what DOTD 1978 probably didn't have the budget to visualise, and what 28 Days Later shied (disappointingly imho) away from in some respects...a cataclysm that horrifyingly strips the veneer away from civilized society in a shockingly short space of time.

The two films can (and should) co-exist, and I for one loved them both, but for very different reasons per film.

8/10

title: As compared to the original
review:
From the first 15 minutes of the film, I quickly decided the newly revamped Dawn of the Dead was my new favorite horror film. This feeling carried me to the very last moment of the credit reel. The directorial style and cinematography brilliantly blended new aspects of thriller genre camera work, basic narrative portrayal, and the same kind of old school shots found in the original version of the film. This adaptation picked up the horror where the original version left it more as subplot for the in-your-face down-your-throat satirical attempt at political statement and assult to capitalism and the blossoming consumer market. Don't get me wrong, the political aspects weren't entirely unfounded and were well thought out in some aspects. It was saturated with symbolism and hit on some major discussions of the time. My problem with it was it wasn't about the zombies! If I want political rhetoric, I'll watch an Oliver Stone flick. If I'm watching a movie entitled "Dawn of the Dead" I want zombies. I want ripping and eating and blood and gore and let's not forget fear for lives and too-close-for-comfort escapes.

The new version was full of all the aspects I crave in a good horror film. Suspense, gore, character connection, and those nice little moments where you actually pop up from your seat a bit. Honestly, I must admit I don't know what makes the original a classic but I am surely glad they decided to do the remake. Granted there were a few holes in the plot, moments that you say to yourself, "Why the hell didn't they just do that a couple weeks ago if that was an option?" However, I suppose that's just a constant in the horror genre. If everyone was logical not nearly as many people would be killed, situations could be better averted, and we would have no plot to unfold.

title: The right balance for a modern horror movie.
review:
I have never been a fan of the serious horror movie. There is nothing in those movies that can break it up a little and achieve a little balance and reality. With the new Dawn of The Dead, the humour serves to remind us that even when death and destruction seems inevitable there can be some fun to be had. (Esp. love the scene of the movie-star looky likey turkey shoot - made me laugh out loud)

There have been some people who say the old ageist comments that only a young, MTV style generation can like this movie, and it is probably pitched at them anyway; but i think those views are getting a little old. anyone can like this movie if you just view it for what it is: pure entertainment at the movies. A little scary, humerous, and has a fairly decent direction. To be honest most types of horror have been done before anyway so you are scratching the bottom of the barrel for original ideas. this movie with its up-to-date slant makes it more interesting than the original. Die-hard classic horror fans wont like that but all i can say is: don't get stuck in the past!

All in all i thought this movie was well worth my √Ç¬£5 and I would see it again if i had nothing to do on a spare afternoon. 7.5/10.

title: pleasantly surprised
review: I went to see this movie with some trepidation as I am a big fan of the original trilogy of the dead.  I refused to even watch the Texas chainsaw remake as I hold the original to be one of the all time horror greats. Saying that though, i was intrigued, and felt the gorier moments of the original 'Dawn' were tainted by the unrealistic blood effects, so a gorier remake was needed. The opening 10-15 minutes were one of the most exhilarating i have ever seen and called to mind Saving Private Ryan's explosive beginning.  The action is first rate, and very rarely ceases during the whole film.  Throw in a ton of blood, multiple impalings, even more exploding zombie heads and you have a very satisfying blend.  There's even some decent comic moments, a rarity in modern day horrors and the cast all perform admirably, (especially the dude who plays CJ).  The directing is excellent for a first timer, although some ideas are taken from Danny Boyle's 28 days later.  I especially liked the end credits, (don't leave early).  All in all, top notch, and well worth the fee.  Can't wait for the DVD release.

title: just weighing in *spoilers*
review:
Some spoilers below







After finally getting a chance to watch the new Dawn, here are some of my thoughts: Overall it was a very enjoyable and entertaining movie. I believe it stands well both on it's own and as a remake. I didn't find the movie particularly scary, although the baby scene had me going, just to see what the zombie baby would look like (insert Dead Alive reference here.) I thought the new Dawn was an excellent action movie along the same line as Aliens. The characterization was cleverly done without sticking to too many cliches. Sarah Polley's character Anna shows that "heroine" no longer has to mean "tough chick." Ving Rames was his usual badass self, his best work since 'The People Under the Stairs' (kidding.) I especially liked Michael, as played by Jake Webber, he was noble and heroic without being overly cheesy or idealistic. The moviemakers did the right thing by not trying to develop characters who only serve as window dressing. The yuppie, the hot girl, the hick, the trucker lady, the dying dad, the crying teen with the dog, and the 'other' security guards are just that, and have little pretensions about being anything more. We even have a couple changes of character, CJ the security guard starts off as a selfish, hostile asshole and eventually becomes a willing sacrifice. And Mekhi Phifer goes from a level headed, practical father-to-be to homicidal and delusional. As stated beofre, I enjoyed the action in this movie, however I would have liked to seen more gore, more 'munching' scenes. I guess they figured that the 'zombie feast' scenes are Romero's domain and are better left to him. Of course you can't have a movie called Dawn of the Dead and not have an exploding head. The zombie head in the ice chest was also a nice touch. Overall, a good movie, not just for us zombie freaks, but for the general populace. That's just my opinion, I could be wrong. -Ray

title: A fun modern remake... not to be confused with the original classic
review:
Dawn of the Dead (2004) might not be in the same league as the original but then it isn't trying to be the same movie. The writers have successfully taken some of the original concepts and created a new movie from them.

I felt this version had a lot going for it. It had me on the edge of my seat for much of the movie. The suspense works well and the characters develop in ways you don't expect them too.

I also liked the fact that the zombies are much more mobile than in previous movies (more like 28 days later than the shambling creatures from earlier movies).

This makes for a lot more intense scenes especially when characters are being chased.

I can't help feeling that if this film was not a remake people would consider it a modern classic.

title: You gotta see this one !!!
review: I wasn't sure if whether the original could be outdone or not. I am happy to say that this remake was totally AWESOME. The acting was great,the special effects were great and overall,I was very impressed. I am hoping that there may be a sequel to this once that all is said and done. The ending did place a little doubt in ones' mind as to what the outcome was. The updated version of how the zombies moved and carried themselves was definitely needed. The fact that the zombies moved as fast as a normal person made it even more exciting and convincing. I guarantee you that if you take it upon yourself to go and see this movie,you definitely will not be disappointed. I took a friend with me to see it who really isn't into horror flicks and science fiction,but he left the movie theater totally satisfied. He said that he couldn't wait for it to come out on DVD.

title: Zombies in the movie theater
review:
SPOILERS AHEAD

The "Dawn of the Dead" remake did not scare me in the slightest. For me, blood is just blood, and this amount of splatter desensitizes me after awhile.

One thing I certainly do not want to see ever again is someone shoot a baby. Even a zombie baby. It was absolutely despicable and breathtaking in its tastelessness and I have a high threshold for tastelessness. Hey, guys, ever hear of smothering the baby or humanely putting her to death? In fact, why kill her at all? Despite her appearance, she's still a five-minute-old baby who was apparently making no move to bite or infect anyone. She can't walk and doesn't have any teeth. What's she going to do, crawl across the floor at a terrifying speed, break down doors with her impressive newborn baby strength and kill everyone?

As a matter of fact, why was I even subjected to that extremely juvenile premise, which I saw coming miles away anyway? It served no purpose other than for the director to say, "Hey, we even killed a baby. How edgy and willing to shatter taboos we are!

Doesn't it make you think?"

Of course, the dog survived, because they always do. The baby died but they couldn't kill the dog, because that would just be sick and cruel and people would be in an uproar. Killing a dog would definitely be beyond the pale. Killing a stillborn baby, on the other> hand ...

This movie made me think about nothing. Sure, the extremely trite theme was how consumers can be zombies. Yawn. I already knew that reading the 19 million reviews of the original and this remake established the theme again within the first 10 minutes and then did absolutely nothing to add to the premise. Worse, the movie clumsily shifted tones from horror to comedy.

If this director wanted to explore the idea of mindless consumers, he should have set "Dawn of the Dead" in a movie theater, as zombies there eagerly swallow this insipid tripe.

title: Well Done Film
review:
Ok. I gave this a 10 of 10 to boost its rating up from a 7.4. This film is not perfect, but it is good. I'd give it probably an 8 or so. It is not like the original in terms of social commentary. I wish it had more, but it would have needed to be 30 minutes longer. This was an awesome action flick.

While some say that you dont care about the characters, I disagree. The one blonde chick, OK, i dont know her name either. She was hot. Real hot. CJ was such a badass that you had to love him, Ving Rhames was awesome, and the a few others you really cared for. And a handful you really wanted to die...Painfully... And they did.

Overall, if you like Zombies, guns, action, or horror, this movie is a definite must see. Catch it in the theaters so we get a sequel!!

--Quickdraw--

title: This was a great movie!!!
review: When I saw this version of Dawn of the Dead of course I didn't expect this to blow away and be even better then the 1979 version of Dawn of the Dead cause hey a remake can not beat a masterpiece.  But the nontheless I still thought this version was a great movie and I enjoyed it greatly, the ending was a bit of a suprise and honestly sort of reminded me of another zombie me called well Zombie back in 1980 cause of the whole island and zombies on the island thing.  Ving Rahems, Sarah Polley, Mihkei Phifier, Jake Webber and the rest of the cast was excellent and didn't do a poor or cliche acting job as other zombie movies do often.  The violence and gore was good, but could of been more graphic and violent like the original Dawn of the Dead was, but of course the MPAA won't allow it so I understand (I guess we will have to wait for the unrated version to come on DVD lol) the fast, running zombies is a depature from the original and traditionally slow moving zombies, but we are in the 2000's now so hollywood has to conform to today's standards so the running zombies are ok.  Anyway to end my comments I do not think this movie in anyway will be nominated for an academy award, but this should certainly mark the return of the living dead or if u don't get what I'm saying the return of the zombie movies.  Now I'm just wondering if the Italians are going to remake Zombie since they made the original Zombie right after the original Dawn of the Dead was made.  Anyway from the looks of it this movie will be a huge hit as I'm writing now 4/2/2004 it grossed already $44,000,000 and still counting.  Shout out to the cast, director, and crew who made this version of Dawn of the Dead u guy's did an awesome job.

title: Classic Remake of Classic Film
review: I'm astonished that this movie is as good as it is.I had heard good things about the job Snyder did with it,but was stunned to find it is as good as Romero's original film.I saw the original back when it came out(1978?)and have been a big Romero fan since.I cant believe I'm saying this,but Romero may have been out done in sheer intensity.Sure,the social commentary which was so out front in the original barely registers here,but this one never lets you take a breath.While watching this movie I found myself so involved with the characters and thier actions that I had to stop myself from hollering at the damn movie screen when they were in danger.I wanted to help them.The acting is really good.The gore effects are stunning.If you like Zombie movies,or love George Romero,go see this movie.A+++

title: Dawn of the Dead...Not a true remake, but a great film...
review:
Romero's Dawn of the Dead is a more brooding film that plays on the mind long after you've seen it. The atmosphere is bleaker, the actors' performances more rounded, the story layered with irony and shrewd observations on the human condition. The zombies win through sheer numbers, being slow lumbering shells of their former selves, and not raging dead athletes with frightening levels of agility, like their 2004 counterparts. They also win because mankind is too stupid to unite, too morally contradictory (example: it's wrong to kill the recently deceased to prevent the spread of the epidemic, yet it's right to be shallow and materialistic...hence shopping mall setting) to survive in a world where all the rules of wrong and right have become less complex as civilization crumbles. The incredibly savage and nimble 2004 zombies are going to win anyway, even in a one-on-one situation it seems. The biology of the zombies in the first film is more believable, and so the scariness of the zombies stays with you for longer, where as the new film's zombies scare you in the short term...like a good white knuckle ride. Romero's are more believable as actual dead things. The lack of coordination through rigor mortis and brain death of the 1978 film suggests 'zombie'. The 2004 film suggests 'demonic possession' or perhaps humans undergoing a permanent living viral madness, a la '28 Days Later.'

I feel that this was necessary though, because the 'shambling zombie' is now a stereotype, and the kind of subtle horror of Romero's generation is (perhaps unfortunately) out of vogue. That's not to say that DOTD 2004 doesn't scare. It's a visceral roller coaster ride that equals 28 Days Later. I'm not sure whether the concept of 'zombies' is communicated as clearly with the screaming athletic rabble of this version though...But the concept of insurmountable odds and impending death most certainly is.

Where DOTD 2004 improves over just about EVERY zombie film ever made, is in its effectiveness of communicating the enormity of the cataclysm...the absolute horror of the rapid decay of human civilization, and the fragility of society. The first 9 minutes, plus the ensuing credits gets the scale of the disaster across perfectly, in a way that DOTD 1978 hinted at, and 28 Days Later SEEMED to be about to do with its wonderfully edited trailers, yet ultimately failed to do.

The first Dawn of the Dead hints at the global apocalypse looming, with the occasional TV/ radio bulletin, shots of the rednecks gunning down zombies out in the countryside. DOTD 2004 actually delivers the goods with the stunning set pieces in the Polley's suburban estate, and then the city, and then builds on that success with a pretty standard, yet exquistely well paced gore-a-thon which takes the zombie film into a more contemporary direction.

A great film, but not (apart from the zombies/ people in a mall similarities) really a bonafide remake of Romero's epic. I eagerly await the DVD release. 8/10

title: Disappointing
review: I have always loved horror films my whole life, always felt that they were the movies worth going out to see.  Having grown up in the late 70's and 80's, I got to see a lot of great films, including the original Dawn Of the Dead among other "zombie movies". It seems to me the "zombie movie" just is not done right anymore. I can easily name 10 MUCH better horror movies of this type. Maybe it was the annoying hand held camera shots and the way the zombies were more of like "video game" zombies, than walking corpses.I hated the make up effects in this film, and the cinematography made them hard to see at times. Seriously for a $26 million movie, I WAS NOT IMPRESSED. I'm easily more impressed by a good old Fulci film like "Zombie" or "The Gates OF Hell". Computer use does not work in horror movies as well as old style "gore" effects. Ironically, I believe Tom Savini pops up in this movie for a minute. The "Gaylen Ross" store in the mall was a nice touch. Gaylen Ross was  an obscure actress who starred in the original. DOTD (2004) was an overall disappointment, but this is coming from someone who has "Zombie Lake" and "Dont Go In The House" in the video collection. I have seen wayyyy to many horror movie and maybe I'm just a little biased to the old "grind house" cinema, more bold and uncompromising, less flashy and quickly edited. 2003 , was a decent year for horror in my opinion. SO far 2004 has been a pretty slow year for the genre and Dawn Of the Dead (2004) just does not make the grade.

title: Capable casting aids suitably scary, partly campy cult remake.
review:
Rating: *** (out of *****)

I hereby pronounce that the remake of 1978's Dawn of the Dead is among the best of the cheap horror films that I've seen in the last few years. Slick and gory without becoming too camp, it doesn't cop out, doesn't bore and even has some wit.

The message of the film is simple - stop the zombies from spreading. They're everywhere! As the poster for the film says, there wasn't enough room for them in hell. And even if you do manage to escape, don't let them bite!

The film doesn't have the kind of character that great horror really needs, but I don't think it ever aspires to such a level. It's just a slasher film with the enemy within being zombies instead of deranged psychos, serial killers or werewolves. It has a tone reminiscent of the overlooked British werewolf flick, Dog Soldiers - that is, quite sardonic & clever, as well as genuinely chilling when you least expect it.

Capable casting is one of the reasons that the film works at all - during the film, you really do feel suspense and a certain degree of pity for the protagonists, even though the character-building moments seem pretty obligatory. It's especially nice to see Sarah Polley (who I haven't seen since 1999's Go) back in action, and Ving Rhames's presence is always welcome (though it's odd to see him in a low budget film).

OK, Dawn of the Dead is silly and unoriginal. But what would be the point of it if it wasn't at least a little of the former? All I know is, after the Wrong Turns and Michael Myers' unwelcome resurrections, you'll find this to be quite a scary surprise.

title: Old vs New
review:
Before I say anything about the movie I'd like to add my 2cents on the old vs new argument.

Hold the thought that "the old one was pants because ...". Just bear in mind that in 20 years time people might be saying the same thing about the current one. Does that affect what you think of the movie when you see it now?

The original Dawn of the Dead does look lame in many ways in comparison to the remake, but how could it not on a $1.5million budget compared to however many multiples of that budget the new one cost? If a movie could be weighed on the ratio of box office takings to budget, the remake would probably have to scrape $1bn to match the original's performance.

Now here's what I think of the 2004 one.

[potential SPOILERS follow]

A great opening and introduction to the characters. Sfx/gore pretty impressive so far but nothing to really make me cringe. The threat of the zombies is well realised and the sense of claustrophobia as with the Romero originals is achieved very quickly.

Now comes the middle section full of tension and "how are they going to get out of here" questions arising. A few more faces get introduced. Fat woman - pretty gross.

Pointless bit in basement where somebody dies and then they get back upstairs. Sorry, so they've gained a dog - not pointless. Definitely better however and more concise than the really drawn out bit in DOTD 78 where David Emge plays basement zombie hide and seek for 10mins.

Zombie baby - sod off you're crap. Second most pointless thing after zombie vs shark scene in Lucio Fulci's imaginatively titled "Zombie". Oh hang on I forgot the zombie family in The Video Dead (the worst film of all time). Anyway, hate the baby - what's up next?

Here comes the biggest drawback of the movie so far. The disease is only spread if you're bitten. This is VERY 28 days later and really should have followed the Romero theme where the *dead* are coming back to life and not just the bitten who then died. For me, that's what was really scary in the first place because there really was no way of stopping it. People die every few seconds.

Now the tough blonde lady brags to shoot man after he's dead. (Sarcasm)Well I don't know, whatever could be coming later then? A suggestion: in order to achieve the unpredictability of the Romero movies you'd have to start by reversing that one and have the guy shoot the woman after *she* were dead or something. Surely it's more likely to scare people if they *don't* know what's coming?

Now if like me you're from the Romero school of thought and you've been used to the baddies getting their just-desserts at the hands of the hungry zombies you were probably waiting for that super-gory climax ... which never happens. Yeah they chainsaw some zombies and a poor girl gets sawed in the shoulder (the highlight of the fx for me) but no drawn out ripping to pieces of those that deserve it; no guts & organ munching for the undead. Real light snackers these Snyder zombies, always up for a quick bite but nothing more. Surprising seeing as they have so much energy.

The ending? It's more of a stop than an end. Not poor though.

Overall, I've been pretty nitpicky with the above comments but then this film *did* have the budget where DOTD 78 did not so I'm backing the underdog.

If you've not yet seen either then I would recommend seeing the remake first as it is definitely more current and it'd be unlikely that you would not enjoy it. Although I've not stated them, this film *does* have many good scenes and ideas and will go down as a respectable remake. However, if you're a true zombie movie fan and have seen a few low-budget movies in your time then it's gotta be the original seen first and the remake after.

Recommended 7.5/10

title: pleasantly (?!) surprised
review:
As a long-standing fan of the original Dawn of the Dead i was apprehensive and a little insulted to hear of news of a remake. How dare anyone presume to remake what is in my opinion a classic movie?!

My initial hostility got me wondering about just how a remake could fail and i decided, to my surprise, that what made the original DotD so memorable wasn't its gory effects, convincing characters or interesting locale but its attempt at social commentary. So jaded have i become over the past couple decades that i expected a DotD remake to be a vacuous, irrelevant Zombie effects spectacular with - ahem! - no soul.

How wrong i was. What i got was not only a finely made movie with some terrific acting, effects and (notably) sound work but also a terrifying glimpse of how life might be if the infrastructures of civilisation were to collapse. And it has left me reeling in its wake. The remake DotD is truly disturbing...

Ask yourself this: "How much do I rely on the goodwill of others and, in a crisis, how far could I honestly claim other people could rely on mine?" and you have the terrifying question raised by this movie.

The central characters, of which there are three (IMO), are altrusitic archetypes: a cop, a nurse and a 'nice guy' with time for everyone. These are the pillars of civilised society, the givers and understanders, but they soon find themselves in a situation where they are faced with selfishness, pride and fear - a sort of hell on earth, as one character observes.

As the film progresses, and the zombie threat grows to truly overwhelming proportions, it becomes more and more obvious that the true threat to the survival of the 'heroes' is the dependability of the people they are trapped with. Should they admit other survivors knowing they may be 'infected', should they just bide their time and wait for a rescue they know isn't coming, should they hatch a daring escape - all of these issues are argued over with the effect that as a viewer I found myself sympathising with all views and wrestling with the fact that my own ethics and morality had become as strained as the characters in the movie.

Not wanting to seem trite or over-reactive, in this day of terrorist threat and tension the DotD movie does raise a very valid and frightening question which left me with a genuine sense of anxiety and dread that i hadn't felt since i was much younger and watching films like the original DotD.

I got what i least expected from this film, it frightened me. But it also entertained and left me with hope for an otherwise flagging horror genre.

Go see it, and congratualtions to the producers.

title: do people just not get it!
review:
Yup, I would say that this is a remake worthy of the original. Yes I know that there are people that swear by the original Romero classic, hell I myself was very apprehensive before I saw this.

As a fan of horror and more-so of zombie movies (Which have been too thin on the ground), this has to be the best zombie movie since the original. Better than the original?...... All I can say is decide for yourself. But as a modern day zombie movie, it has plenty of scares, gore and some good humour makes for a good watch.

As i have just mentioned zombie movies have been thin on the ground, but 2004 seems to be year of the zombie, with the weak and inept "House of the Dead", the impressive and funny looking homage that is "Shaun of the Dead" (Which has been getting some good reviews) "Resident Evil Apocalypse" which looks as if it takes off straight after the end of the first and maybe, just maybe Romero will have his "Twilight of the dead" out on release before the end of the year (but i doubt it). So if like and you are unsure about going to see it, dont expect the original, just enjoy it.......You will.

title: Worth Seeing, even as a fan of the Original.
review:
Ok then, as an avid fan of the original i was sceptical about this new version, whether it could live up to the hype or not.

However, i was very glad to say that i really enjoyed the film. The characters in the film are a nice mix of stereotypes - who complement each other very well while doing well not to annoy the audience. And it's good to see a bucnch of people in a horror film that actually use a bit of common sense for a change.

The zombies in the film are great aswell, they are still primitive but from the trailer you can see how agile they are compared to their 1978 counterparts which of course give them an extra edge that the humans have to deal with. Hats off to the Special FX and make up in the film, they do a great job, the zombies look exactly what you would expect them to be.

There is plenty of gore and action in the film but nothing too over the top, which is mixed in with a refreshing slice of humor aswell. The plot allows the film to build momentum, however, i think in the advent of films becoming longer it could've benefitted from an extra 30-40 mins in the middle.

For fellow hardcore Romero fans: i'd recommend it - good film, and theres some goodies in there for our benefit too.

For everyone else: Go see it, simple as because you'll enjoy it.

My vote: 8/10

title: Great, Not very Scary though (some spiolers)
review: This movie it Defently the gorest movie ive ever seen! At times it is quite funny. Its kinda neat if you leave the theater when the credits start you see them leaving in the boat to the island and you think theyre gonna make it through by hiding on the island. WRONG at the end of the credits it shows the remaing survivors getting off at the dock on the island and theres tons of Zombies there, they dont have any ammo left so they end up dieing. I'm shure you all knew that anyway. My favorite part of the movie was when they where going thru the crowd of zombies outside of the mall, cuting off legs, blowing heads off, propane boms just great!!! Well i hope this review was helpful 2 you later dudes!!

title: Best Zombie movie in quite a while
review:
While there are many zombie movies I have not seen this was just about my ideal splatter-flick. Tonnes of action, lots of tension, decent pacing and enough humour to make you at least smile and remember that it is only a movie.

I doubt it will be up for any awards any time soon, it was as one of my buddies put it "What 28 days later wanted to be". I never saw the original as it looked too "B-movie" for me but I am seriously considering making a dash to the video store today to pick it up.

I will definately be buying this one on DVD when it comes out, and may even go back and see it again at the theater!

title: I love the Dead!
review:
If you are a Dead fan then this movie is for you.

Just about everyone reading this already knows that this is a remake of George Romero's Dawn of the Dead but beyond the title and the fact that the dead have a hankering for munching on the living the similarity (for the most part) ends there. This is an improvement over doing a scene-by-scene remake as was done for the original Night of the Living Dead. I am pleased that the producers decided to add their own interpretation of the genre.

Judged on its own merits this is destined to become a classic "Dead" movie. The Romero movies are classics, especially the first because nothing like it had ever been done before but the action, direction, make-up, and special effects of this (re-)incarnation make this film a must see. The Romero series is looking rather dated and low budget compared to what can be accomplished with the special effects these days. Do special effects and a bigger budget make a good film? Just refer to the most recent Star Wars films and you'll see that that is not the case.

I won't bother with the plot because, let's face it, these movies are about putting ordinary people into extraordinary situations and seeing how they respond. In that context it is easy to understand their appeal. How would you react? Would you just give up and accept your fait, would you fight back or perhaps fight your potential allies for control? This movie covers those aspects similar to how the Romero films covered them, with intelligence and insight into the human character.

The bottom line is if you are a fan of the Dead movies than it is worthwhile to see this in the theatre. The production values are good, the action is good, the suspense was a little lacking but overall this is one for my (Dead) dvd collection.

title: Good effort
review: When i first went to watch this film last weekend i was a bit sceptical after i had heard all the hype surrounding it.  I wasn't too impressed with the first opening scenes to the film, as unlike the original George A Romero trilogy the film seemed to lack the gritty and dark atmosphere they had. The story in the remake seemed to be more inventive and interesting.  I don't want to ruin too much of the story line for you so i will give you my favourite moments.  Watch out for the zombie baby, and the ample sized zombie lady!  The chainsaw scenes were also not to be missed.
