So many times horror films lose steam half way through the film, but Dawn only built up steam. From the first ten minutes one can get a sense that this is going to be a fast paced film, and see that there is not going to be much time to breath. I also found all of the characters to be very interesting, although I thought there were a few too many characters. In the original there are four people who must survive, but in the remake there are a lot more people that we have to watch out for. Many of them were just there to stand in the back, and were cause for a great death scene.

After a hard day's work the only thing that Ana wanted was some r and r, but what she got was a whole different story. The film takes us on a wild ride in the lives of a group of strangers who come together to fight for their lives. After awaking to a horrifying sight, Ana must escape from the man that she has come to know and love. Soon Ana finds herself with of group of other desperate strangers who take refugee in a near by shopping mall. Inside the mall the meet three security guards and take in a rig full of helpless outsiders looking for a safe base. Inside the mall they keep out the living dead and try to go on with their lives while waiting for help. As everyone one knows that all good things must come to an end, so the group which has been downsized, decide to escape the mall and travel to an island where they can rebuild their broken lives. Now with a plan in hand a small group of the living must outsmart a large group of the dead.

Usually in most horror films there are up and coming actors (who can't act scared if a zombie bit them in the ass) who are living in their fifteen minutes of fame. Rarely do we get the treat of watching a group of talented actors scream their way through a film, well in this fright fest we are exposed to a group of very talented actors. Playing Ana, Sarah Polley delivers a strong performance playing an even stronger character. Her mix of rage and beauty helps her to take charge of the screen. Ving Rhames, whom I believe to be one of the most underrated actors, take charge in this film. He is an amazing actor and turns in another solid performance. Jake Weber and Mekhi Phifer play too very different characters and are very believable in their roles. Kevin Zegers and Lindy Booth, who are reuniting a second time on screen after their small roles in another excellent horror film WRONG TURN, play their characters in unique ways. For Zegers, who has few lines, he is very demanding when he is one screen and Booth, plays the helpless girl to a tee. While all of the other actors deserve to be mentioned I think that by saying they all do an excellent job is fair enough, because many times audiences are not paying attention to the performances the actors are giving anyway.

Dawn of the Dead truly is a film worth seeing. There are good performances, a solid recreation of a classic, an awesome score, many scares, and even a few laughs. If you haven't seen it go see it right now stop reading get in your car and go¬Öif not for anything else go to at least check out the ending. Dawn has one of the best endings to a horror movie that I have seen in a long time it is scary and original. I am going to give Dawn of the Dead 3.7 stars out of 4 and an A-!

title: Much better than expected
review: I was looking forward to seeing this one with just the slightest bit of trepidation. After the god awful Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake, I was afraid this would disappoint as well, I'm glad I was wrong. The acting wasn't anything spectacular, but in the case of Dawn of the Dead, who goes to see great acting. The pace is fast...so fast I was afraid to blink. The undead were not the plodding idiotic zombies of days past, these things are relentless, and super quick. I really enjoyed this film. I'd rate it a solid 8 of 10 Also in closing...SPOILER ALERT I've read several reviews that say they hated the sappy ending....well stay through the closing credits...its not as happy as we are lead to believe...in fact it ends rather badly for our heroes.

title: Rent the Original
review:
I am a fan of the original "Dawn of the Dead". I was in high school at the time and it was the first movie that really scared the bejesus out of me. The extreme gore, and the heartpounding opening sequence where a group of people escape within inches of their lives. This movie feels like it would've been better with another rewrite. It's too scattered to feel that sense of danger. Only the 3 main characters thankfully have a bit of depth. When the rest of the troop bites it over the the course of the movie, it's little more than scorekeeping for the audience.

At least the film tried to explore a couple different angles from the first. But it feels like the first film had a bigger budget. There are stretched out moments with no action, even our friends the zombies don't appear for long periods of time. I liked some of the morality play, and Jake Weber does a solid job as the voice of reason.

I just didn't get the heebie jeebies like I thought I would. "28 Days Later" got some good attention, because you could sense the fear. A tighter script with more action would have drawn you in more. Nevertheless, the success of this one will draw out a sequel. Maybe there will be better ideas and a better budget next time.

5 out of 10.

title: The Best
review: The internet, because it is so high-tech, allows for many useful functions and uses. One of them is to let me tell everybody (who can read) how f***ing spectacular this movie is. No previous zombie film... maybe even ANY horror film... comes close to delivering as much terror and awe as this theatrical legend does. Any pessimist or coffee shop-employed, movie critic wannabe can just shove a cracked baseball bat up their ass instead of bitching about how "It wasn't as good as the 1978 version." or "It reminded me of 28 Days Later...) WAAAH!!! Cry me a river and drown yourself in it, douchebag. This piece of work has a potpourri cast of characters that really beautifies the film and makes you think "It's great that these people are here, respecting each other as humans, charging foward each day in an attempt to survive... however, it is sad that it took a tragedy of this magnitude to get them here." Besides the characters, it has a great soundtrack for the type of film it is and shows vast improvement over the 1978 versions cliche disco-horror music. The lounge-version of "Down with the Sickness" and the closing credits song are absolutely fantastic. The movie itself is a great evolved piece of George A. Romero's screenplay and is a testament to his genius and Zack Synder's courage and prowess.

title: Great movie!!
review:
This movie was almost as good as the first one which is a complement since the first film is a classic. There are many movie remakes these days which try to show an updated version and usually ends up being very "cheesey". While there are a few things I would have not done with this film it is VERY entertaining. While the main idea of the movie is here and has many parallels to the original there are many differences as well.

Some of the similarities are the zombies of course, once you get bitten you turn into one. Shoot them in the head and they die. The few survivors take refuge in a mall.

The differences are the speed of the zombies. The origional had them walk slowly towards you which, in my opinion, makes it more suspenseful and makes the zombies look more ... well dead I guess you can say. The fast moving zombies in this version is exciting as well but just gives it a very different feel. More of an adrenaline rush then a scared feeling. There is no biker gang in this one which was a really nice touch in the first. And in this movie seemed more of a stand-alone film while the original was obviously a sequel where everyone knew about the zombies from the beginning, again in my opinion was a little better since we already know what the zombie problem is about.

Some of the things I found to be kind of stupid in this movie (and there are only a few) is when ***SPOILER ALERT*** Nicole (the young girl in the movie) went out in a truck to save the dog. And she actually made it. Give me a break... If it was that easy to get food to the guy in the other building they should have done so earlier... Another thing is the way they hooked up the trucks... reminded me too much of the old show the A-Team... and why did they put bobwire on the tops of the trucks... they are zombies who do not feel pain. Why put them on there. Also there were many zombies in the parking garage where the trucks were? And lastly... I wish we got to know the characters better... they all seemed a little flat.... and they should have shown Mekhi's character going a little nuts to explain better why he acted the way he did..... other then these few things I thought this move was perfect...

Hopefully this helps some. I think everyone who loves horror, action and black humor would enjoy this film. Hopefully this movie will pave the way for more zombie movies and may have George Romero make a fourth installment to his living dead movies.

title: A masterful reinvention of a classic
review: Upon seeing Dawn of the dead 2004 I  was amazed at how they took the classic and only made it better.  I am a fan of the original dawn and felt this interpretation was good. With the advances made in the make-up effects industry, the zombie look and attitude was much more animalistic. which I think make the zombies more of a threat. the casting was a stroke of brilliance. No it isn't the original, it's not ever going to be and doesn't try. That the best part of it. This film I feel will stand on it's own. Remakes are the big thing now and some classics being remade is going to be bad. But I think this film is not one of them. Dawn of dead 2004 is another success of the remake era. so check it out you won't be sorry.

title: Freaked me out
review:
I have been waiting for "Dawn Of The Dead" for weeks. My favorite movie as a youth is "The Omega Man", and this is a more visceral, exciting film. No morality plays or super heroes here. Just some very ordinary people who trying to survive the unimaginable.

The key to a film like this is seeing it in the right locale. I chose a theatre in the 'hood, and typical of urban filmgoers, the audience was unrestrained with their reactions. Even I started yelling directions at the screen (mostly like "Shoot her") when the survivors would do the stupidest things (I guess people in horror films have never seen a horror film).

Ving Rhames gave his usual superlative performance as an implacable police officer/bad ass. I especially liked Jake Weber as a nobody who rises to the occasion, but without any surfeit heroism.

There was little character development or social commentary, but you were at the wrong film if were expecting that. I liked the small touches, like the coffee bar's name, "Hallowed Grounds", or the relationship by binocular with the stranded gun shop owner across the road.

Bottom line, after my friends dropped me off, they politely waited until I got into my building before driving away. As I soon as I saw them pull off, I ran into the street chasing after them, like a zombie in the film. They were laughing madly as they sped away, just like they would if a real zombie was after them. I doubt I would have such a fun and spontaneous reaction if we had just come back from "The Seventh Seal".

title: Excellent movie, but not worthy of the moniker.
review:
It is certainly refreshing to see a movie like Dawn of the Dead is doing so well in the box office. This movie was beautiful in it's presentation of the apocalypse, full of dramatic camera angles, pulse pounding situations, and a realistic view of how people would act when faced with almost certain doom.

With the above being said, it doesn't deserve the name Dawn of the Dead. Despite the originals obvious shortcomings, i.e. cheesy make-up and techni-color blood, the originals story was much better. It's presentation is stark, which in my opinion adds to the realism. And the original is much gorier, which is part of the reason I see zombie movies to begin with.

The similarities between the two movies are weak, basically being trapped in a mall, and the strong characters being a woman and an African-American the only similarities (for those of you who are younger, this really was an important issue back in 1978, with the original Dawn of the Dead getting praise for it use of different types of heroes). The monsters of the new film, and the zombies of the old are not even comparable; they are completely different in their nature.

I congratulate the makers of this film for what it was. I wish it would have been released with a different name, since I feel it still would be successful.

My rating is an 8/10.

title: they are 2 different movies by 2 different directors
review:
Romero's original film had a great sense of space and timing, and four great characters that he let you care about . With the remake they piled up a bunch of people and it wasn't much of a surprise you knew most of them were gonna get chopped up and it didn't seem to matter because you didn't get to know them any way.

The only reason to call this dawn of the dead was the theme of the mall. Romero already made dawn of the dead and it's still great. And in all honesty I love those blue green zombies and all the bright red blood.

My heart was racing for the first half hour of the remake , it was terrifying . but the only people I felt sympathy were for poor Andy and Matt Frewer, playing the doomed dad. The best I can say about the new movie is , It was genuinely scary, and they didnt even try touch romero which was a smart move ,but.... the ending sucked I am not a fan of the snuff endings where they kill everyone. the end credits reminded me of something they didnt use for the s****y house of the dead euro crap.

It was scary and that was goood for me I didn't expect a Romero masterpeice.

title: Recommended!
review:
Saw it yesterday.

WOW!

I wasn't sure I would like "fast" zombies (haven't seen 28 Days Later yet - so won't compare).

These zombies were SCARY.

Well acted, well shot and the editing is good (not great). The story is about as good as it gets for a zombie flick.

This version WORKS and it works VERY well.

The Opening scene is creepy to the max and before the title, you are in no doubt of what is to follow. Probably the best build up in a zombie flick yet.

It begins with a "normal" day in the hospital for an everyday kind of nurse, Ana (Sarah Polley), but soon, the world is turned upside down and shaken.

Ving Rhames, as Kenneth, is AWESOME and I actually felt RELIEVED when his character entered the picture.

The acting is solid with performances by Jake Weber `Michael', Mekhi Phifer `Andre', Micahel Kelly `CJ', Bruce Bohne `Andy' and a bit part by Matt Frewer that is poignant and effective.

I was impressed by the casting. I was immediately and easily able to suspend disbelief and accept the characters as `real'. I do not expect character studies in these films, I expect sketches and fairly 2 dimensional attitudes. Kenneth, Michael and Andy were my favorite characters, but all of the `A' parts were well acted.

What was REALLY nice to see is that they stayed away from the Survival Horror stereotype characters - perhaps even introducing new ones. The characters responded `realistically' and "logically" to their situations (based on THEIR perspectives and perceived values.)

Andy on the Gunshop was clever and a very interesting part of the story.

While there are indeed some SHOCKS, I regret to say that they did "pull some punches". While not as pornographically gory as the Italian Splatterflicks or even the original, there were definitely guts, blood and exploding heads. But Private Ryan still holds the title for pure gore (I haven't seen the Passion yet). This was disappointing because instead of an original zombie flick this was a remake of a classic, one that defined a genre. To whimp out on the gore is nearly unforgivable.

Also missing was the campiness of the original, though there are plenty of intentional humorous incidents to punctuate the horror. Also gone are Romero's social commentaries. This film isn't about society, it is about surviving the insane.

The original holds a special place in my heart and I was VERY concerned about the remake - Hollywood has screwed up a lot of decent opportunities lately. I am pleased to say that this film was "done right".

Could it have been done better? Sure, but it will do as is, at least until the "uncut" version is released on DVD.

BTW, I really liked Savini's remake of Night of the Living Dead and in many ways prefer it over the original. Not that it is better, but I think it is better executed and I liked his spin. Therefore, since I liked the remakes of NotLD and DotD, then I actually look forward to and HOPE they remake Day of the Dead.

The Mad Hobbit's rating: "See it now".

SPOILERS:

Setting the stage with longshots of the city were AWESOME - a LOT to look at and just enough time to look, before we go back to action. In the first long shot of the city, watch the lower center of the screen at first, before gazing at the rest - you will have time.

The meeting of Ana and Kenneth was a bit contrived, but trust me, the movie quickly gets back on track.

The intro of the mall brought a delighted giggle from me.

The editing is a bit muddled at times, occasionally `skipping parts' that you need to mentally fill in, for instance how they gain entrance to the locked mall. These are few, and easily ignored, but I couldn't help but wonder why the cuts were made.

I wasn't fond of the change in how the dead are created. Bite only seems to make it a virus, I always preferred the `we just don't know' explanation.

A lot of people complained about the absence of `character' zombies, like> the Hare Krishnans, cheerleaders etc. I actually didn't mind the loss, in fact it would have been distracting.

I didn't like the whole dog storyline and thought that they pussied out by passing on some zombie dog possibilities.

Also, when the girl `Nicole'(?) goes to 'rescue' the dog, not only did I groan at the clich√É¬© but I couldn't help wondering that if it was so easy for her to drive over to Andy's Gun Shop, why didn't they do it earlier?

When they finally leave in the shuttles, I still am not sure why the second one crashed - I felt it was again `contrived' instead of `natural or logical'.

BTW - do not jump up when credits roll, throughout the credits are glimpses of the REAL ending of the film. Which is not only cool but raises ANOTHER gripe, and a reason why I can't rave as heartily about this film, we really don't get to SEE the zombies in this film. Oh, sure there a few obligatory scenes, but the glimpses in the end credits really had me wishing there had been MORE.

title: Great Re-make
review:
first of all, this is not the original. When you see it, if you have seen the original, think about this movie as if you have not seen the original.

it is a good movie. also the little girl in the beggining is not the daughter of sarah polley, it is the nieghbor. so therefore they would not have heard the screams.

Spoiler----- When the are inthe gun store, how do they get out cause they just sorta appear ouitside all of a sudden. that is the only thing that bothered me.

It is agreat movie if you take the original out of your mind. But nothing is ever as good as the original. so forget it.

title: great as a regular movie
review: this one blew the old one away. there wasn't a drawn-out part of this one in which the survivors just hang out. that's taken care of in an entertaining montage. there's better action, more plot, more characterization, you're with the characters more. there's so many stages to the movie, so much happens. it isn't a satire like the original, which works for this movie. it works like classic adventure stories work: it's about people finding strength and sticking together in incredible struggles. it's the best "regular" movie of any zombie movie i've seen, and perhaps the best zombie movie. one of the ten best movies of the past year or two. the classic was fantastic. this one was better.

title: why oh why do we pay taxes?
review: I didn't really think this film would affect me this much but I found myself thinking about an exit strategy IN CASE we ever get invaded by zombies. Sad isn't it? The film makers succeeded in doing their job. They give blood, gore and thought provoking situations to confront yourself with. If you don't take life too seriously and haven't become too jaded by life then you'll enjoy yourself and leave asking "what would I do in this situation?" and laugh about all the nasty stuff you just saw with your friends. If you ARE that over serious, hard-to-please type then you'll leave the theater asking "why did I just waste my money on THAT?" like the sour-puss walking out of the theater next to me. He was thankfully the only one who didn't enjoy himself and his friends told him to shut up and mellow out when he became The-Director-Who-Could-Have-Done-a- Better-Job, we all know that guy unfortunately. The beginning of the film before the credits rolled got the audience to clap and cheer, it was just that exciting and brutal. Civilization at the very moment of collapse, the point where 911 fails, police and paramedics just can't do their jobs anymore and our main characters are left to jump in their car and floor it to safety. Excellent fun. If you want a possible happy ending, LEAVE when the final credits start. If you stay through the credits you'll be left with a sad, disturbing ending which I was not happy with because I just wanted everyone to finally be safe, and thats not what happens. If it were me on that boat I would have.....

title: Review: Worth catching in a theater
review:
First of all, before you spend your hard earned 8 bucks, if your looking for a film that will win any awards or touch you in a spiritual way, stay home. But if your looking to see a good zombie flick with plenty of thrills and gore, you should definately check it out.

As with any remake you will have the usual critics that will tear the movie down just because its a remake, wheither its good or not. Dont let them make up your mind for you.

The basic plot of DOTD remains the same though there are many changes to the storyline which are always welcome. The use of gore, I think was almost perfect. Not too much, and it was in very realistic ways. Also, the humor was kept to a minimum. There are a couple of one liners that could have been left out but not enough to pay attention to.

The ending was left wide open for a sequal, which I would welcome if done in the same style by the same director.

To sum it up this was the BEST zombie flick I have seen. If you enjoy a good horror flick, check it out. You wont be disappointed.

title: Different, but not necessarily bad
review: As a zombie purist, I too was concerned about the newer, faster zombies. I guess we can thank "28 Days Later" for this development.  However, once you get past that objection and just go with this film, you'll find it's not that bad as a stand-alone horror film.  If you keep harking back to the Romero trilogy, you'll probably be disappointed, but if you look at this as an update of the earlier film (as was the remake of "Night of the Living Dead" where Barbara was no longer a wimp), you may actually enjoy it! There are so many more characters to put in peril--let's face it, having only four main characters in the 1978 version limited the potential for carnage. There's lots to like about this film, including the variety of zombies (babies, obese women in slips, etc.), a cameo by the motorcycle gang leader from the original, chainsaws, and other innovations.  As to those who complain about the ending, remember the ending of the original?  None of the Romero films had satisfying endings, so why are you so upset with this one? When can we expect an updated "Day of the Dead"?  I'm ready for it!

title: Great Movie in its own right!
review:
Ok, I though they played this one perfectly! When is a remake not a remake: When it is completely re written from scratch. The mall was a plot device used to give fans from the first movie a familiar "place to call home" Other than that it is not the main focus of the movie as in the first one. Next you may tout Romero and put the 1st version on a pedestal but, Romero did a great job with the budget he had. the first was campy and the zombies shuffled around slowly but hey it worked! In this movie as in all of the "DEAD" movies there is never explanation given as to why it happens it just does! Even with the better makeup and increased action the Dead aren't the focus as much as the interplay between the characters and their isolation.

My main issues are with the credit scenes. They sail off... to where? they are in Wisconsin the clips make it look like they are out of water so; last I checked they couldn't be at sea! The fuel thing was ridiculous they are in a sailboat. And why couldn't they fish for food? Eventually the DEAD would decompose and slowdown. And why in the remake of Night were the dead fighting over a rat but they don't eat dog?

title: Good, yet not good enough
review: Being a faithful follower of George Romero's Dead trilogy (Night, Dawn, and Day), I was somewhat satisfied with the remake of Dawn of the Dead. It has great action!!!! However, it lacks in some areas. There are too many characters, thus leading to a lack of character depth. The running zombies just didn't cut it for me as it reminded us of the ghouls in 28 days later (i.e., seemed like a sequel to 28 days later at times). Finally, if the dead are returning to life, then why is it only those who have been bitten?!?!?!? Those shot or dying of natural causes do not re-animate!!!! That's a major difference from the trilogy and Romero's concept. MAJOR FLAW in my opinion. On the other hand, the action is great and does an amazing job at causing tension and anxiety in moviegoers (I think I checked every room in the apartment when I got home). Also, the story line is good enough to maintain one's attention. I suggest loyal and new fans go see the remake, all will enjoy!!!! Little piece of ADVICE, stay till the end of the end credits.....there are some extras to the story line...don't leave the theatre until everthing is done!!!!

title: Run, don't walk to this flick!
review:
For the record, the first 10 minutes of this film alone were worth the price of the ticket. These scenes litterally had me on the edge of my seat as Ana takes flight in a world gone hopelessly insane.

That being said, I have to ask: Don't any of the critics get it? So many of them are pointing to the lack of humor in this remake of the 1979 classic, or saying it moves way too fast. Baloney! Why does it have to be funny at all? This is a horror movie about the end of the world, for Pete's sake. And does anything today really move at the same slow speed that it did in 79?

Dawn of the Dead 2004 is a fantastic film, finally bumping 28 Days Later off of the notch as the scariest movie in years. I'm a huge fan of the original Dawn of the Dead, but I eagerly anticipated this remake. The movie takes itself seriously, gives us a troop of heroic people to root for, and never lets up on the heart-pounding pace.

It's interesting to note that many things that were important to the original - race relations and rampant consumerism - seem less important here. Maybe we're finally reaching the point where skin color just isn't an issue. And the mall itself, where the survivors pathetically try to hole up, doesn't even seem to be as strong a character as it was in the original. It's also interesting to note that the blood and gore, so shocking in the Romero version, doesn't shock at all now.

It can't. We all too quickly get caught up in the great characters. Sarah Polley, she of the deadpan delivery, has an undeniable screen presence. Ving Rhames is terrific as the tough cop, the very character you'd want to have with you when the world is ending. Jack Weber makes a completely likeable good guy, and Mekhi Phifer's desperate attempts to protect his pregnant wife are touching and tragic.

I had a few gripes with the sound track here and there, but for the most part, it was on target. And I loved the choice of a Johnny Cash song for background in the opening scenes.

If you go to the film, stay until the last credit has rolled. It will tell you how the story finally ends. If you miss it, you'll miss the end of the movie.

title: BETTER THAN 28 DAYS LATER
review: I think you have to have a certain mindset going in, when you see a movie like this. But I was blown away. Stunned. Awed. At times hilarious, but never campy, this truly scary movie is the most "human" ZOMBIE film I've ever seen. The characters are written with true depth and it really says a lot that this movie attracted truly top notch actors. Everything, even down to the music selection, was incredible. The tone of the movie was perfect. The way everyone worked together and eventually became a team really seemed realistic...not a bunch of hokey, horror movie cliches. Containing one of the most frightening opening sequences you'll ever see, this is simply a movie I'll never forget and will enjoy for years and years.

title: Good Stand Alone Zombie Movie
review:
I went to see this movie on Friday night, I liked this movie. I tried not to get my hopes up too much because the original is such a great movie.

I think this movie was more of an action movie, where the original was more creepy because they built the characters more and there were less action sequences.

The new version was made more creepy for me, having it based in Wisconsin, hearing the Milwaukee Emergency Broadcast System, seeing Milwaukee Squad Cars, and the County Bus. Hearing that Miller Park is no longer safe. Living in Milwaukee all my life, having these points made it a little more realistic for me.

Also very cool were the cameos by some of the cast from the 1978 version of Dawn. Scott Reiniger (Roger/General), Ken Foree (Peter/Televangelist), and Tom Savini (Motorcycle Gang Member/Sheriff). Those were the three my friends and I spotted.

Anyway, all in all it was a good movie, but not in the same category as the first.

title: Even though different from orig it was done very well
review: Even though this movie was shot differently and the details were different. It did have the same gist of the previous release.  Also what is great, the ending makes a more seamless transition into day of the dead.  And the cameo from Tom Savini was great.  I am sure not many people picked up, but it was great!  This movie could not have been remade any better.  Zack Snyder did an excellent job!  I have seen all the others several times and I could watch this one over and over and over as well.  For someone to remake a classic sets them up for disaster if they are not careful and this remake was an absolute success!   I could go on and on about the differences between the original and this one.  But is not worth it, as they are two distinct  movies that stand out.  Can't wait to see what else is next, as many classics are being remade.

title: When there is no more room in Hell, the dead will sprint the Earth. - Spoilers
review:
I do not understand the idea of remaking good movies. I think I'll re-paint the Mona Lisa. Why not remake bad movies? Just think, a big budget remake of Plan Nine from Outer Space. Then again, if you wash and polish a piece of crap, it's still going to be a piece of crap. Ignoring the fact that it is a remake, the new Dawn of the Dead is a good movie. I would call it a gore filled action movie as opposed to a horror movie. It was not scary at all. 28 Days Later is more of an actual 'horror movie.' Not many modern horror movies are actually scary any more. They have become so post-modern that it is almost impossible to have unique scares anymore. The good thing about this movie is that it does not take it self seriously. James Gunn set out to write a balls to the wall zombie movie and that is exactly what he did. It is obvious that he is a student of Lloyd Kaufmann. The zombie baby scene is something right out of the Troma Universe. It is obvious that Gunn is a big horror movie fan. He knows all of the elements to throw into the mix, like the a*****e you hope gets killed, the comedic yet gruesome death scene, the 'getting and plan and preparing to kick ass scene,' and countless others. He is the perfect person to write a 'horror' movie.

I can do without the MTV style of editing in movies these days. Dawn of the Dead is full of that and it gets annoying and confusing to a degree. The cinematography was great though. It had that kind of grainy look that any horror movie should have. The picture also seemed to stay clear and focused while the camera was rapidly moving around too. The new Dawn of the Dead is a treat for any zombie fan. The whole argument that the zombies move too fast is just silly. There are no rules for zombies because they DON'T EXIST, so film makers can have them do whatever they want them to do. I think they are creepier when they are slow moving and lurking around, but who cares.

The remake ignores the capitalist and consumer oriented society metaphors because they were already explored in the original. That would have been crossing the line of remaking into just ripping off ideas. Have fun and go see the remake. I'm sure Mr. Romero will forgive you.

title: Definitely "re-imaged" but a great "remake"
review:
I enjoyed this more than the original DOTD. My major gripes about this movie were the plotholes, the lack of character development (most of the time you had many characters you could care less about), and the running zombies. It just doesn't make sense. HOW do the dead RUN??? Instead of overanalyzing it, I sat back and enjoyed it on opening day. There were some humorous scenes (the infamous celebrity-look-alike zombie shooting spree scene, uhh hello, that did NOT look like Burt Reynolds!) and even scenes that made me cry- namely the scene between Lindy Booth & Matt Frewer (you'll know what I'm talking about if you saw it) and the part where Andy holds up the sign that says "Hungry" and you could see his ribs. Pathetic I know. I never thought *I* would cry at a horror movie.

In any case, the Richard Cheese version of "Down With The Sickness" was hilarious and a great cover, it wasn't as gory as the original but it was good. Definitely kept me on the edge of my seat. I plan on going again.

I give it a 9/10.

title: An Insult to Zombie Fans Everywhere
review: Do not waste your money on this weak remake of Romero's minor zombie classic.  All of the negative comments I have read on IMDb I pretty much agree with --- and most of the positive ones I truly wonder if the critic saw the same movie I did.  In over 50 years of being a movie fan, I have felt like walking out of the theater less than a dozen times ... and this was one of them.  I toughed it out, hoping that the massive plot holes would somehow disappear (like the psycho mall security guard who changes character at least three times).  I like a good scare, but I was never even close to flinching even once.  Want a good scare?  Go rent the original "Dawn" or, better yet, the granddaddy of em all: "Night of the Living Dead".

title: a new Dawn beckons...
review:
First off, allow me to address all those who feel compelled to lament this new "re-imagining" of the 1978 classic as a weak attempt at a re-make. Notice I said "re-imagining". What would be the point of making a shot-for-shot re-do? What novel and and ambitious qualities could possibly take shape? Well many do, and I am happy to say the new Dawn of the Dead breathes a welcome, albeit supercharged "life" into the zombie genre. True, Zach Snyder's undead don't waddle and plod along with blank stares, which made them much more "corpse-like" in the original. Romero's zombies, despite Tom Savini's (who makes a precious cameo in this one) innovative make-up on closeups, for the most part looked like they needed a tan and a napkin to wipe the ketchup off their chin. The 2004 Dead are vicious, fast, and driven by pure animal instinct. Many comparisons have been made to 28 Days Later, but let's not forget the baddies in that disappointing venture were NOT zombies, but people infected with a cross between rabies and steroids. I havent seen any comparisons to the old 1977 Marilyn Chambers classic (no, not Beyond the Green Door) from David Cronenberg called Rabid, or the 1985 sci-fi Lifeforce. Both featured similar, fast-moving "deadish" villains. And the list goes on.

What makes this new Dawn so mortifying (forgive the pun) is what it DOESN'T tell you: like how the plague started, how universally spread it has become, where the helicopters fly off to (surely there are military safe zones if these yaps can hold up in a mall for so long), and exactly what happens to the bite victims. Yes, it is not airborne, as the film depicts, but slowly sickens the victim to the point of death, but not for long...as soon as the brain "shuts off", like a switch the disease re-animates the flesh--only now the person is on survival auto-pilot: with an incredible rage and craving for food: good ole living human beings. Why not the dog or each other? Your guess is as good as mine. Perhaps it's a primal scent thing, who knows. Again, it's what keeps you guessing that proves so effective, along with that on the edge of your seat, adrenalin-pumping tension that these zombies provide and Romero's antiquated automatons simply do not. To compensate, Romero indulged in "feasting" shots of zombies gnawing on flesh for way too long (which Italian zombie movie directors took to new, um, heights). This Dawn doesn't need to splash the screen with the grotesque, in-your-face-gore that will make you upchuck your popcorn. But it will make you jump and spill it once or twice!

As for the criticism that the movie lacks the social commentary of the original, well, duh, it's not 1978 anymore! The egotistical consumerism of the 70s Romero so aptly lampooned is for our generation passe, and we can turn to I Love the 70's on VH1 for that now. No, today things are even more fast-paced, high tech and bleak. The film captures that brilliantly (a minute in, a doctor wonders if he will make his golf date on Sunday--isnt that a social jab?). Is it The Real World meets Night of the Living Dead? Perhaps, but only at its most basic level. Are there too many characters? Yes, but these days a horror film needs at least two hotties (who will make obligatory spreads in FHM and Maxim, i've no doubt) and enough ingredients of this wonderful melting pot of ours to satisfy our reality tv craving as much as they ultimately feed the dead. Besides, havent we become braindead zombies when it comes to the crap they spew on tv and we eat up without reservation?

I do wish the film were longer to allow us to explore the central characters of Sarah Polley, Ving Rhames, Mekhi Pheifer and Jake Weber more. There is a central and integral bond between the four that goes below the surface of their superficial mall-mates, but we only catch glimpses of it. The original was 40 minutes longer, and it was to character development that it devoted the extra time. The closest we get to that, as others have noted, is the sentimental and doomed relationship between Rhames' stoic cop and a marooned, rooftop owner of a gun shop across the sea of zombies in the parking lot below. I also wanted the film to slow down and take a chill pill once in a while, which would only heighten the thrills once things started to heat up again. Some shots, though, looked like they were taken right out of "Saving Private Ryan" with its bled-gray, choppy footage, and this element I think added to the "warlike" hell of the film. Kudos to commercial director Zach Snyder for not making this a long and saturated MTV video...but a sleek, intense and stylish film. The biting (again, forgive the pun)humor provided by Ty Burrell is a welcome treat, and highlights a clever script that doesnt become weighted down by a multi-layered, deep plot. Save that for a movie without flesh-eating zombies, ok?

So overall, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND seeing this film. The first 10 minutes is the stuff of sheer cinematic horror brilliance (wow did Johnny Cash's Man Comes Around work perfectly), the middle will have your heart pounding out of your chest, and the end offers the action-packed climactic showdown with the mall zombies you've been waiting for...just DONT LEAVE WHEN THE CREDITS START TO ROLL...(HINT HINT) 8 stars out of 10.

title: Excellent action for the Zombie fan.
review:
I think the Original Dawn of the Dead (1979) is the best horror movie ever, when I heard of this movie coming out, I was scared they might damage the original. However, I was excited that another Zombie flick was coming out and I threw away all expectations before seeing the film. This new version is superb.

It contains a lot of violence, and is probably one of the scariest movies ever made. I would not compare this to the original because it is taken from a different point of view. Any real Zombie fan must take this into consideration or your will ruin a great movie. These Zombies are more vicious, faster, and smarter.

This movie is extremely fast paced, which makes character development weak, but that is not why you would want to see this movie at the theaters. The acting is performed well with the brief time each character has to present themselves. Ving Rhames and Sarah Polley do an excellent job also with their allotted time.

The Soundtrack is superlative for this movie. The editing was good with a large amount of assemble edits that work really well through out the movie.

title: some just might like it better than the original . . .
review:
I've really been looking forward to giving this a chance since i heard about it some time last year, and I've got to say that this really wasn't the movie I expected. It was WAY better! Zach Snyder has put a fresh spin on an old idea. It's really impossible not to compare this with its 26 year old predacessor, but that not what I was really interested in. This is a rethinking of the story. New characters. New locations. New zombies even. In case you haven't heard the zombies run at full speed now. While I will admit that I wasn't too thrilled to hear that they were messing with a perfect formula, it does work perfectly for THIS movie. Lets face it, zombies of the old days aren't very scary in this day and age and especially not from a director that had previously only worked on music videos with fast cuts and quicker pacing. I'm not knocking the guy, its just that with the pacing of this style of movie, I think the fast zombies work much better. This movie doesn't let up for one moment.

The tension never lets up in this film. Not only was I leaning forward waiting in anticipation for the next scare, but I was also very interested in the survivors. All the characters were drawn out very well, and you really become interested in what will become of them. There are plenty of nice situations that arise that are very subtle homages to Romero's classic as well as some of his other films as well. Without ruining anything, I will say that there are at least 2 character types from each of the original classics. Long time fans won't be disappointed with the story.

The effects were great. From what I have heard, there were some CG enhanced scenes, but I don't really think anyone noticed. It seemed that they were using rubber and fake blood for most of it, but some of the gorier scenes had me wondering how they would have done it. All the effects were very well done. A movie like this MUST have outstanding effects to stand out. It reminds me of the over the top effects that were prevelent throughout the 80's horror movies, with each new one trying to top the last by killing someone in a creative way. There were at least a dozen times where you could here the whole audience simultaneously cheer and gasp over a creative scene of gore.

Overall, this was a great movie for horror fans and action fans alike. It won't win an Oscar or anything, but thats not what this kind of movie sets out to do. You should be going to the theatre to be entertained, and that's exactly what i paid 8 dollars twice to go do. I always seem to be critical on remakes of classics, but this one is different enough to look at it as a seperate movie all together. These kinds of movies don't show up very often, and its nice to see one get released with a nice sized budget and get a wide release. All you purists out there don't worry about this being a crappy remake. Once the studios see that this knocked "The Passion of The Christ" out of the number one spot on its opening week, there will be a whole slew of crappy zombie movies out there to target your rants at. Enjoy it for what it is and don't trust scuzzy mall security guards! :D *****

title: the dead is back
review: this was a great scary movie,i was scared to death as all of the other people who was watching it,  my girlfriend doesn't like the dead movies as much as i do but she went with me and she was scared also.the actors and actresses was great in the movie,i wish i could have been a zombie in that movie,the only part i didn't like was that the part where they had to shoot the baby but again i guess i would have too just to survive the ordeal,just think if it ever could happen it would be heck to deal with in real life.i give this movie A +++++++++++++++++++++++++ all the way i am going to see the movie every time i can in the theater as much as i can,when it comes out on video i am going to buy it to add to my collection.

title: The dead are back.
review:
May contain minor spoilers

The dead are back. Dawn appears to be part of a string of neo-zombie movies that have hit theaters recently, including Resident Evil and 28 days. This one, however, is the first to be directly inspired by the original zombie mastermind, Romero. Dawn was the most engaging of the original dead series, and is the clear choice for a remake. It is the brilliant juxtaposition of a setting familiar to all consumers, the mall, and an outrageous situation, zombie chaos. Romero also tossed in a hearty dash of consumer bashing as the zombies waltz around the mall to ludicrous background music.

The 2004 version of this film takes the same concept, and injects it with a fat syringe full of adrenaline. The zombies no longer stumble around, and bump into things. They are ruthless hunters that know exactly what they want, and know that they have to haul ass to get it. This makes the movie a much more tense experience than the original. Snyder takes the serious (almost dry) nature of 28 days later, and blends it beautifully with humanistic (at times silly) tone of the original.

The key to the success of Dawn, however, is that it is unlike most recent remakes. Planet of the Apes or Bedazzled, for example, were both asinine remakes that whither when in the light of the originals. The complex ideas were lost, and replaced with action and special effects. The Movies were not updated; they were numbed for a modern audience. Snyder, Gunn, and company were able to update the film with out numbing it down. Sure, there is a lot of gore and some CGI, but the story is still controls and reigns in all the special effects and big budget hoopla.

Of course the film does have its weak points. One that comes to mind is when Ving Rhames attempts to recite a line from the original. It is a thoughtful hypothosis on why the zombies flock to the mall, but Rhames gives the introspective line an awkward tough guy quality. Still, Rhames shines in a bathroom scene with a little bit of religious rhetoric.

Colorful (but perhaps stereotyped) characters, fast moving action, interesting situations, the scariest zombies to grace the screen yet, and all based on a Romero classic. Justice has been done to the original, and the bar has been raised my friends. This film breaks new ground for edge of your seat zombie mania.

Zombie Fans 10/10 General Film 8.1/10

title: Was this a remake?
review: I saw this movie yesterday and found it to be a gory squelch-fest with beautiful undead effects  and the proper tension between the remaining few humans in the Mid-West, but I can't actually call it a remake. It has a mall and a cop and hordes of zombies but it is a different movie on every level. This has no real social underscore and their aren't two schools of thought on how to deal with the zombie problem, although they begin with a two camp face off that is quickly thwarted .I am a fan of this movie and I rated it a 7-8 out of ten, but the original (not to sound all film snob)is a better picture .If this film stood on it's own instead of having the same and being shadowed by a genre classic it would be viewed as a "28 days later" or "Dellamorte Dellamore". -Erich

title: Pretty good.
review:
I thought that this movie was pretty darn good. I had a decent sized amount of gore along with plenty of laughs. I loved the part in the elevator with the music playing. I don't know if this film is as good as the original because frankly, I have yet to see the original. But if everybody is correct in saying that this version is crap compared to the original, than the original must be a freakin' gem. I give this a 8/10.

I don't want to give to much away but I do want to mention possibly one of the scariest parts is with the baby. Those who have seen the film will know what I am talking about.

title: Intense
review: I am a huge fan of Romero's Dead movies and I must say this movie gets my full approval. I was completely hooked from the beginning. The fact that the whole movie was shot in my hometown also added a lot of enjoyment to the movie, the beginning sequence looked like it was happening in my neighborhood, which was really cool.  The idea of running zombies made me hesitant at first, but they served the story well.  The only complaint I would have is I wish it were longer, and I was expecting a biker gang to crash the mall, but those complaints are very minor.  Solid movie from start to finish, don't miss it in theatres.  I'm very interested to see how the new resident evil will compare to this.

title: Scores the hat trick
review:
I use an ice hockey term in deference to this latest of umpteen recent Canadian imports: "hat trick" means scoring three goals; this movie avoids the three killer mistakes often made by horror flicks post-"Scream," and let's hope it's a trend: (1) No jokes or self-deprecating references. (2) No attempt to "explain things." (3) No lame attempt at a "happy ending." This is just a straight-up gore-fest and delivers the goods.

"Dawn of the Dead" was my least favorite of George Romero's legendary zombie trilogy (which probably puts me at odds with about 90% of his fans) so not only did I have no problems with seeing a remake, I was hoping this would be an improvement, which it largely is. It borrows elements from the original "Night of the Living Dead" and also "Day of the Dead" and retains the original "Dawn"'s premise of taking place mostly at a shopping mall. Since the satire on American consumerism isn't a particularly novel idea any more, the remake wisely doesn't play it up, in fact omits the key plot element from the original of the roving biker gang and the climactic inside-the-mall battle against the zombies. It also adds some new elements (see under "Spoilers").

Sarah Polley (Canada's answer to Uma Thurman?) finally outgrows waif status as a no-nonsense nurse working long hours underappreciated by the doctors (I'm sure nurses in the audience can dig that). There's a conversation in the hospital about a patient who may or may not be an infected zombie, but we never see him, so we never know. She goes home and just has time for the semi-obligatory steamy shower scene with her paramour before all hell breaks loose absolutely out of the blue. (We're informed this takes place in Wisconsin, although I would have preferred Pennsylvania as a nod to Romero.) Her escape sequence is stunningly filmed, much of it through her cracked car window, and reminded me of scenes in Polanski's "The Pianist" with the protagonist observing chaotic action from a strictly subjective viewpoint, making it seem as disconcerting to us as it must to her. Eventually she meets a shotgun-wielding cop played by Ving Rhames who has yet to find the star-making vehicle he deserves. This probably won't be it either, since he's not required to do much except glower and shoot, but boy is he fun to watch. The nurse and the cop stumble across some other survivors and as per the original, take refuge inside an abandoned mall. From then on if it's blood and violence you crave, you definitely get your money's worth.

****************** SPOILERS ************************

In order to jack up the tension level among the non-zombies, the absent roving bikers are replaced by some gun-happy redneck mall security guards whose sheer bloody-minded-ness is the only element that seems a little forced. (I mean heck, I was once a security guard and so was my brother, and we're both pretty nice guys for the most part.) The chief security guard, who at first rivals the fascistic army captain in "Day of the Dead," eventually changes his stripes completely and even becomes a noble self-sacrificer, but then "battlefield conversions" are a movie tradition. There's a bizarre sequence where a vaguely lowlife character straps his pregnant girlfriend to a bed and waits for her to give birth even knowing she's "undead"----hey, how's that for "commitment"! Unfortunately the director feels compelled to show us the zombie-baby---well, using the imagination's for sissies anyway, I guess. The remake expands upon the original scene with the gun store by placing it in a building outside the mall so the owner can develop a long-distance friendship with the cop, even conducting a chess match by using signs. The gun store owner also passes the time by sniping at the zombies milling about in the street, with the others encouraging him "Hey, get Burt Reynolds" or "Rosie O'Donnell." Too bad they didn't name any government officials, but then these are tense times in the entertainment field. We even see a scheme by the mall dwellers to use a dog to convey food to the gun store owner, since they're confident that zombies only eat humans, not dogs. Well, how do they know that? For that matter, why don't zombies eat one another? (Not "afraid of germs," are they?) How come it takes them so long to get inside the mall? Why would the entire military apparatus of the country just immediately disappear? (The original "Dawn" handled that by suggesting that the zombie attack had been ongoing for a while.) When the armored truck reaches the marina, how do they know which is the right boat, since the owner's dead? But then who really cares? We're here for the thrills and jolts. The ending's a slight disappointment: could have been an ass-kicker rivalling the close of "Cannibal Holocaust" but it's intercut with the closing credits and left mysterious as to what happens; gee whiz, are they angling for a sequel to the remake? Aren't there any NEW zombie stories to tell?

The actors all carry their load, especially Jake Weber from HBO's "Mind of the Married Man," which just for the record I wish hadn't been cancelled. Weber can convey a lot with a little and, being British, could play both the Kevin Costner and the Hugh Grant regular-guy roles. Fun to see Tom Savini reprising the police-chief role from "Night of the Living Dead" ----"Shoot 'm in the head and burn 'm" ---although I wish they'd used the classic exchange from that scene:

"Are they pretty slow-moving, Chief?" "Yeah, they're dead.... they're all messed up."

One minor quibble: I'm sure every modern mall must have at least one computer-oriented store, so it would have been a nice touch to see the characters go on-line trying to make contact with someone. But to borrow a line from Alex Cox' "Straight to Hell": "Still, mustn't grumble...." I'm just glad they were able to get this made and released in theaters before (if a certain incumbent office-holder gets re-elected) this country becomes a guilty-pleasure-shlock-banning theocracy altogether.....

title: At last a re-make to be proud of!!!
review:
Wow does this happen to be the best re-make of all time? I have'nt seen TCM remake yet but if its half has good as Dawn remake then its will still be excellent.

The film follows a similar story as the original but is injected with Nitro as its pace picks up to lightning fast with ever rising tension. I loved the characters and alot there are too, although i will state we dont get to know them as personal as in the original, we do still feel emotions towards them. I liked how CJ's personality altered throughout from Arsehole to Hero, while Steve goes from not sure to Arsehole.

There's loads of gore and for once political correctness has been thrown outta the window, somthing unusual for a big budget big company these days.

If your into horror and you have'nt seen this film yet then I suggest taking a day of work and seeking it out.

Excellent!!! 11 out of 10

title: Easily the Best Horror Movie of Recent Memory
review:
I had wanted to see the original before I saw this remake, but when a friend asked out of the blue if I wanted to see it, I couldn't resist. I still intend to see the original, but this 2004 version was a excellent film in its own right. I didn't find it very scary, but I didn't go to be scared. The zombies were very well done, the added humour really offsets the more graphic scenes well. I found that they took your mind off the theme of the film, so when the action set back in, it would catch you off guard. The ending left me a little disapointed, but it wasn't all bad. I found that as a horror movie, it was better than most of the more recent horror films I saw, like F vs J, and Jeepers Creepers 2. Well, only other thing I can add, is that the action scenes were great, plot was decently done ( I have a few holes I noticed), movie was a bit rushed, but its not a big deal, and as said before, watch the end credits, it will be worth it.

9/10, excellent movie.

title: In one word I can rate this film...
review: Just saw the "remake" of Dawn of the Dead 3 days ago. After much emotional debate with those in my group and with myself, I feel I can (in one word) rate this film... LACKLUSTER. There was NO apparent reason whatsoever for this film to have even been made. The plotline is so flimsy (Quote "Lets go to the mall")... hey, why not go to the gun shop right across the street, you morons! The character set-up gave the audience no care for them whatsoever! The only person that actually evolved in the film was CJ the security guard. Just for those that posted otherwise... the CGI was AWFUL! The crowd at the theater we saw it at (including us) was laughing and shaking their heads at the ridiculousness of many of the situations. This movie looked like a poor 28 Days Later wannabe! Besides a few head shots, there were no cannibalism shots! Maybe a neck bite... but where was the intestines being devoured? A few good side effects here and there (chainsaw in the shoulder), but they downsized the gore in lieu of some sub-par CGI and a cut rate script. If this movie did not have the Dawn of the Dead name, I would have seen it in a month and a half (if it was still playing) and still would have had a bad taste in my mouth. I rate this one below 28 Days Later (and I am using that as a comparison even though it IS NOT a zombie movie like all of theses dumb-ass critics are calling it) and the HORRENDOUS House of the Dead. Save your money, watch the original... you will have a better time!

title: Worthy remake
review:
I always go to see horror film remakes, no matter what anyone says, "oooooh, it's an insult to the original" and all that rubbish. I see it as more of a tribute. There have also been a few excellent remakes, "The Blob", "TCM". So i went into this with medium-level hopes.

Well i can honestly say that this is the most exciting movie I've seen so far this year. From the jumpy beginning to the ominous end, every scene kept me interested. There are even a few to make you laugh and remember that it's only a movie.

The zombies move a lot faster than they did in the original, the sprint at you screaming, something i believe that the filmmakers tried to cash-in on "28 days later"'s success. However, they improved on the zombies in "28 days" by managing to make them look like zombies, not merely nutjobs with red eyes, thus adding to the creepiness of the whole thing.

The characters in the film are not enything special, but the actors play their parts well and present a realistic interpretation of the situations that they face. However I don't think that the slight attraction between the nurse and that bloke was needed as they never really explored it enough.

I had read a review telling me that the film was not that violent, this disappointed me at first, as I like my horror films with added red stuff. This comment was proved wrong as the film more than satisfied the gorehound in me. Highlights include an armoured vehicle plowing through a crowd of zombies with a chainsaw sticking out the side, and a stick being thrust through a zombie's head lengthways, plus some wicked head explosions. The other thing I liked about the gore was that it was rarely enhanced with computer graphics, it went back to the old skool methods of latex and squibs, this gives a much more realistic view of the gore. NICE!

All in all, one hell of a movie, and definately recommended to fans of the original, I know that I might annoy some people by saying this, but I thought it was better than the original, which i found quite boring, even though it was far more violent. Oh well, you will have to see for yourselves!

Note: Watch out for Tom Savini making a cameo as a policeman on T.V, and that other bloke from the first DAWN whos name I've forgotten also making a cameo appearance.

Oh, and you get see one of the charchters having sex, and you see her boobies, which was nice. Pointless, but nice.

title: I Loved It! It Wasn't THAT Great! (mild spoilers)
review:
When I stepped in to see the remake of Dawn of the Dead, I did not have any idea what to expect, but I must admit I halfway figured it to be a let down.

First, I LOVED IT: In a way unique from the original, the cinematography was shot well enough to really draw you into the action. This was the movie that, in my opinion, "28 Days Later" should have been. The atmosphere was very well conveyed and had a strong sense of realism, while maintaining a sense of Hollywood style, and I enjoyed the sudden thrills which were very unique from the original. The entire movie, everything about it in my opinion, is better than any horror movie has been for quite some time. I liked many of the situations, I liked the plot, all of the cameos, including the store called "Gaylen Ross", and I thought it was very seriously, and whole heartedly done by all of the main characters. I also LOVED the intro with the Johnny Cash song, which I thought conveyed a feel similar to what George envisioned for the original.

But, It Wasn't THAT Great: Nowadays, scary movies have to have soundtrack reminiscent of the Slipknot or Marilyn Manson sound to be considered a REAL scary movie. George's movie wasn't just scary, it was eerie and depressing. A big part of the "DOTD '79" atmosphere was that you could see them all around you getting closer and closer. The remake was more like, BOOM! they're here, now they're gone. While the new version is indeed a thrill a minute movie ride, the original was a work of art that had many things to say about us and our society which added to the eerie nature. I also liked the original's smaller cast. Since "Night Of The Living Dead" had already happened, it was more conceivable that there would be fewer people around, therefore making the situation more progressed and that much more hopeless. I also find a slower death more effective than the quick killings of the modern slasher flicks. And the nudity in the newer version was not artful/incidental nudity to help the story along like the very brief nudity in Romero's original. The original cast was more intimate, more dramatic, and more down to earth. Though the newer version had somewhat better acting (in some cases- i.e. Ving Rhames) and better effects, the original plot, script, and atmosphere, were of much higher quality and had so much over the new one given the time period. I thought the original was funnier, eerier, and I thought the make up jobs they did on the foreground zombies (not the plain blue faced ones) were better looking than the newer disease-esque zombie look.

Conclusion: Go see the new one if you're looking for a polished Hollywood style slasher/thriller type zombie flick. I'm going to go back and see it again. But as for the original, "Don't knock it, it's got it's own key."

title: George Romero, RIP
review:
The fears of sacrilege were misplaced!

Snyder and Gunn's "Dawn" remake is more terrifying, visually intelligent, and unsettling than Romero's groundbreaking 1978 film. No one who loves horror will wish for that masterpiece to disappear: it's always going to be a brilliant sardonic take on the themes of 20th century American decline (consumerism, social Darwinism) and its radical vision helped take US horror cinema out of a long oafish funk. But the original "Dawn" is wearing its aging deathmask somewhat lopsidedly today. Next to contemporary work like this remake and the icily brilliant "28 Days Later," Romero's shambling rotters are at risk of becoming the equivalent of ghosts in sheets, just as the once-poignant setting of the shopping mall is no longer revelatory as it was in the 70s. Boo! is not the same for every age.

The new film lifts its sprinting zombies from Danny Boyle and its ideas, structure and best lines ("When there's no more room in hell...") from Romero. Everything else is Snyder's feel for the texture of the new American century, frail and uncertain of hiding behind banal excess: in fact, the genius of the film is to locate its opening set piece in the midst of an anonymous, pre-fab American suburb--the very heart of sham solace. By the time we escape to hunker down in the mall for the start of the second act, the torn landscape outside is as savage an apocalyptic vision as any yet on film.

Snyder's cast is likable, his eye good, and his luck in an editor and fx crew superb (we are treated to an astonishing cgi spectacle: a veritable ocean of the dead). Gunn's script is perfectly serviceable, even without Romero's nuances. 8 out of 10.

title: New Dawn of Zombie Movies
review: I liked New Dawn of the Dead because of the faster pace action as compared to the OG Dawn of the Dead.  Tell the truth if you walked outside and saw 20 Zombies running at you instead of walking slowly towards you, it would be alot more frightening. It makes the movie more believable with faster zombies coming after you, and makes the scenes more intense.  All you people who think this movie sucks because of fast zombies should step into the new millennium.  Anything I don't have problems running away from and taking out with ease doesn't scare me, something that is jumping, running, biting, hitting, kicking to try and kill me does.  Come on are we Michael Jackson in thriller where the slow zombies can catch you? The only thing I did not like about the movie is it seemed like no one was smart enough to put on extra clothes to try and prevent a bite. That guy named Julius is one cool MF though. They had a sporting good store didn't they?  I would have put on a rubber suit as soon as I found out that the bite kills you. @¬ø@ U Peace out!!! Bring on the Day of the Dead Next I give this one 9/10(That's two high fives)

title: well worth the price of admission for me
review:
Not a "remake" so much as a "revision" of Romero's famous original. While some of the more appealing elements of the original are gone (like most of the "mindless mall rat" aspect of the zombies), and others of the original rules are bent or broken, I'd still rate this as the best zombie movie since, well, the last Romero-inspired film (Day of the Dead).

With a bigger budget, bigger stars, and bigger effects, the movie is somewhat more of an action film than the original Romero series...and that worked quite well for me. My own personal rating of a flick like this depends heavily on the creep factor, the adrenaline factor, or a combination of both...and as far as I was concerned it delivered.

Could this movie (and last year's far more turgid 28 Days Later) signal the revival of the true horror flick? Well, yes, it could. I personally found it refreshing to have zombies that moved fast -- and the nature of the film is powered up by that notion. Imagine BlackHawk Down crossed with the original Dawn of the Dead. There are a number of big, fast-paced, grab-your-attention-and-don't-let-go sequences that had me gritting my teeth in both tension and enjoyment.

Final analysis -- there are only a few obvious improvements that could have been made, I'll go see the flick again for a second round of enjoyment, and I'm already looking forward to the eventual DVD release. Two thumbs up (that's all I'm equipped with).

(Oh yeah...did I mention? All the blood looks =real=, as do virtually all of the gore effects, a rare event in any horror film).

title: AMAZING!!
review: Let me begin with the ending. DO NOT LEAVE DURING THE CREDITS ROLLING. If you do, you will miss so many things. My Husband and I went to see this movie on Friday night for the opening and we so impressed, we went back the very next day and watched it again. Seeing it twice in a row took nothing away from it. When we saw the film on Friday, we went with friends. After we left we all decided we needed a drink because we had all felt like we had been on a roller coaster that just would not stop! When you leave the cinema you are just freaked. You start thinking to yourself, what if this really did happen? How would you survive, what would be your plan? As we left the cinema which was also in a MALL we decided we could find better places to go that were more advantageous than a MALL. This new film in no way takes anything away from the original. Yes, the zombies are faster but they have evolved. I didn't really think that character development was all that important so for that reason I was not disappointed that the characters were not very well defined. Let's face it, the zombies are the true characters that needed defining and it was given through the film. I screamed, laughed, cried, screamed some more and applauded at points but as I said at the beginning, if you leave during the credits rolling you miss some very important points of the film. If I am being illusive it is because I don't want to give a thing away. Just keep in mind, you are going to see a film that is about zombies so don't get caught up in the character development or anything else. Sit back and buckle your seat belts because you are in for the ride of your life. Enjoy the film and watch it more than once. Don't compare it to 28 days because that isn't fair. They are 2 different films in their own rights. This film was awesome and to those of you who love to bring your kids to the cinema, DON'T!!!!!!!!!! This film could truly have them having nightmares for a long time. We noticed a lot of people with kids and ther ages anywhere from 6-13 and for me that was a bit much. I would never bring a small kid to see this one! If you read all these posts you can see that most adults are having a hard time with it so imagine the imaginative mind of a small child. Get a sitter.

title: YES! Better than the original!
review: Now let's get one thing clear right off the bat...I LOVE GEORGE ROMERO'S ORIGINAL MOVIE!!!! It is one of THE classics of horror. BUT....the remake surpasses it! Some have written that the movie makes no social statements. WHAT? Okay, the original made digs at consumerism by equating the zombies with mindless shoppers. However this one has a more profound subtext for a few of the characters. One of the survivors is pregnant. So the question is raised, as it is by many people in the real world, "How can I bring a child into a world that's so screwed up?".  The characters here also deal with an issue that the survivors in the original did not...what happened to their loved ones? In Romero's movie, NOT ONCE do the characters ever wonder about the fate of their friends and families. That issue is at the forefront of the new version. So to those that say there is no human drama here....what movie were you watching? But all that is incidental, what everyone wants to see this movie for is the zombies. Let me say to the purists out there....shuffling zombies ARE NOT SCARY!!!!! You can simply run, or in fact walk, right past them. Try that in the new movie. These flesh craving monsters will run your ass down, and be snacking on your vital organs before you can say "undead". Now THAT'S scary! The cast is excellent. Ving Rhames is the man, and owns every time he appears onscreen. Sarah Polley is a hottie, and maintains a cool head throughout. Jake Weber is very identifiable as the nice guy "everyman". You really care about these characters, and hope to see them survive. There is also great humor here. While on the roof of the shopping mall, our heroes communicate through large, handwritten signs with the owner of the gunshop across the street, who has retreated to his roof. There is a great scene where the on the roof of the mall, with binoculars, pick out zombies that resemble celebrities, and then have the gun shop owner blow them away. Also watch for the shop owner and Ving Rhames using their message boards back and forth to play chess. There are many nods to the original here, but they are very subtle. Watch for the heroes of Romero's version in cameo's. My favorite homage is right at the beginning of the movie. As Ana is driving down the road, we are treated to a high ariel shot looking down at her car on the highway. A helicopter flies in and out of frame. It is the same helicopted used by the characters in the original movie to escape the zombies that have overrun the city. So in the end, a great movie. Great tension. Great scares. Great humor. Great gore. A great treat for all horror fans.

title: Welcome to the End
review: "Dawn of the Dead," remake of the original 1979 film, delivers on all fronts.  It starts with a bang, submitting us to some very scary and disturbing imagery (my favorite being the bus window scene).  "Dawn of the Dead" continues the trend of updating the zombie for our time.  Back when "Night of the Living Dead" came out, it was supposedly a parable for communist paranoia - they could be anyone, anywhere, even our neighbors, and they're OUT TO GET US! The slow, encroaching threat of the red nation... "28 Days Later" showed us zombies that were based somewhat on modern tempers going to hell.  Air rage? road rage? consumer rage? There's a reason the virus was called "RAGE."  A metaphor for how seemingly decent people becoming virtually feral at the drop of a hat in our society - I see this up close every day, so that hit home with me. Here, the zombies take a note from 28 D-L and are faster, smarter and more vicious than any movie before.  Their speed and violence is also a perfect metaphor for terrorism in our age - it comes so suddenly, with such an amazing cost to humanity, and it seems that we just can't stop it no matter what we do.  It's everywhere we go, and it's not going to go out without taking a few of us with it. The writing of the movie is tight and pulls no punches.  This is a horror movie in the TRADITIONAL sense.  Forget that teen-level garbage with a bunch of nubile high schoolers being chased by some idiot in a mask.  This is a callback to when horror movies were written for an adult audience, and they're not out to be gentle or provide tongue in cheek humor.  They go for the jugular and they don't stop until they're holding half of your throat. This is an excellent, excellent movie, one that was well crafted, well acted and genuinely scary.  Intense and frightening in every sense of those words.  If it suffers from anything, it's a slight lack of character development, but they got more development in than I was expecting. 9 out of 10.  Twenty-first century horror has arrived, and it's not for your kids anymore.

title: A Stylish Remake that Strays from the Understated Beauty of the Original
review:
Let me preface this by saying I am a HUGE fan of the original Night of the Living Dead and Dawn of the Dead. I think Romero is a genius and his movies are really smart. The original Dawn of the Dead is a really sharp social commentary disguised as a basic horror movie. It takes on issues about interracial relationships, class, American nationalism, the role of the media, and most of all the original film is a HUGE critique of glossy, homogenized, consumerism.

The new Dawn of the Dead is... a glossy, homogenized, consumerist movie! Yeah. Put that in your pipe and smoke it Romero! Just about everything that made the original so sharp and biting is gone. This movie really shares very little with the original except the general premise, a few scenes, and maybe 3 lines of dialogue. So I was disappointed. I think if you've never seen the original, you might enjoy this because it is, like I said, a pretty glossy and well-made horror film.

The good: This film sets the scene probably better than any other horror film I can think of off the top of my head. I really likes the way the film established the premise so quickly, it grabbed you before you had a chance to get your guard up. I only wish it was the establishment of some OTHER movie other than a second-rate remake of one of my favorites. The acting was fine although nobody had much material to work with. Ving Rhames as the macho-military-guy character was a brilliant stoke of casting. Effects are appropriately slick and animated. I missed the neon blood of the original, but there was more than enough reddish blood to go around.

The bad: This movie takes very little from the original. What it takes, it re-envisions very poorly. Many of the scenes are in different order, so they're sort of disjointed and confusing. The mall is severely underutilized. This film could have happened anywhere, the mall is merely incidental-whereas it was the central heart of the original. My real problem is that the scenes from the original Night of the Living Dead and Dawn of the Dead resonate so STRONGLY that to re-make them in a different way is really hard for me to swallow.

Fast zombies. Super fast zombies. Superhuman zombies. Which is all well and good, who am I to tell zombies what they can't and can't do. The problem? I think the Romero's slow moving zombies are scarier. Sure, you can outrun them and dispatch of them individually really easily. But that's not what's scary about zombies. What's scary about zombies is that they multiply, and multiply, and MULTIPLY. and the combined strength of thousands upon thousands of slow movie zombies is that they're everywhere. It's suffocating.
