They take over, They're methodical. They slowly but surely get you. And THAT, is suspense. Fast movie zombies, in my opinion, removes what makes zombies special. If they're fast, they might as well be vampires-right? It's the slowness that makes zombies different.

Maybe it's just me, but I found this movie to really cop out on the whole interracial relationship angle. They don't allow Ving Rhames and Sarah Polley any sexual tension. Instead, almost as a throwback they give us a different interracial couple (who we all know are zombie meat anyway) rather than explore the issue through the main characters. That's such a cop out.

In the end, this is a fast-paced, well shot horror film with nice effects. It's not the biting social commentary Romero's classic is. Pun intended.

title: remaking a classic - pack a lunch
review:
Hey heres a tuff assignment - remake a classic film. Yeah, here you go take 30 mill go to canada and remake one of the best horror films of all time. You are going to have at least 10 times the money, 10 times the time, 10 times the people. Can you do it? Well probably not but hey don't feel bad. I wouldn't want to try and make a movie called Dawn of the Dead.



Im a huge fan of the original like lots of you are. I was 3 however when it came out so I wasnt at the theatre. So i was excited to go see this version. I didnt hate it like several of the people i went with

(i mean i'm a fan of dawn of the dead) thats the way it is. Its just funny that 25 years later with tons more money they can come up with so much less than the original. I guess they though they could just dial in the old trusty 90 degree and 45 degree shutter angle on their cameras and the story and details would compensate for itself. Thats about it I'm disappointed but not really cause the original is still there so whats there to get fired up about.

title: Good, but not great
review:
I saw the original "Dawn" when I was 22, and it was the best horror movie I'd ever seen. Probably still is. However, I am not a "purist" who has a problem with someone remaking what are considered to be classic films (except perhaps for "It's A Wonderful Life"), so I was really looking forward to seeing the "Dawn" remake.

Although the movie has its moments, it doesn't hold a candle to the original. Maybe it's just the difference in my age, but this one didn't shock me the way the original did. The tongue-in-cheek humor was probably a little better than the original though.

Is it worth checking out? Absolutely. Especially if you're a horror/zombie fan. Is it worth waiting until it's released on DVD (hopefully with lots of extras, deleted scenes, alternate endings, etc.)? Depends on how much you love horror films, I guess. Having seen the film, I would say it's not a must-see film.

Some of the other posters are correct - DO NOT leave when the credits start running. Geez, I couldn't believe how many people hit the exits without realizing that the film wasn't really over.

title: A none stop trill ride
review:
This movie kept my interest from start to finish, even though, it has the same name of a movie i've watched at least 10 years ago for the first time(im young). When I first heard about this movie I was like everyone else, very uneasy, knowing hollywood was remaking yet another classic. But not only was this a remake of THE zombie movie, I mean the phrase zombie movie and Dawn should be stimeutanous with anyone that is a fan of the genre.

Now on to the remake. I went in this movie expecting nothing close to as good as the orginal. And thats what I got, but this remake is a total different movie. I appreciate the pace that it goes, although sometimes you find yourself catching up to the story, over the brisk pace. I think this is by far the best zombie genre movie to come out since Return. For a zombie and Action movie, this is a Gem, that delivers all the goods and more, it is a None stop trill ride.

Go see it with an open mind, I dont think youll be disappointed.

title: Resident Evil, eat your heart out
review:
I'm not normally a big horror fan, as a majority of the "horrors" that I've seen have, at best, only one good jump-inducing scene, with a few cheap obligatory "shock" moments that rely more on surprise than horror to scare you.

Dawn of the Dead is intense. Really intense. Intense intense intense... the pacing of the action beautifully creates the feeling that everyone is just hanging on for their lives, and breaks are few and far between. About mid-way through the action slacks for about 10 minutes, and I felt myself welcoming the mental break almost as much as the characters themselves.

This is a fun movie... make sure to see it with a group of friends, and don't get up to go to the restroom. And unlike most other zombie movies, the zombies are actually pretty scary... I've heard a few complain about the idea of a fast zombie, but the slow, shambling zombies of resident evil look absolutely lame in comparison to these fast, screaming unfortunates.

This is horror at it's purest- the crap's been cut, the action is inense, and nothing is sacred. Wow.

title: A New Dawn
review:
****MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS****

I went to the theater with a lot of anticipation and was not disappointed. Well maybe a little, but these are my pet peeves and on a whole are not meant to diminish what I felt to be a future classic remake of a classic.

With all of the "Dead" movies you find that you instantly put yourself in the character's place and while there are going to be differences in thought and action, I felt there were "General" concerns/emotions not being addressed by the ensemble cast that were addressed in the first one(s).

It's like they accepted this plight without enough question and just rolled with staying alive, So that there was an underlying frustration/chaos throughout.

As a result I felt this affected character development to a large degree. Where were the individual "war" stories discussed between the survivors regarding what they saw, heard and went through before linking up?

The news coverage was disjointed, frenzied and lacking. It would have been slicker to have at least one station still reporting with more information as the movie went along.

Reporter: Q: " Are These Things Dead? "

Government(?)Speaker: A: (With sweaty exasperation) "....We just Don't know..."

In essence, this set the tone of the movie...a hopeless, frustrating, swift and almost total armageddon! And yes, it's obvious that this was intended.

I recall now at the start of the flick the character of Sarah simply clicking past the news on her car radio while looking for her easy listening station that sounded like "....Reports are still sketchy..."CLICK..."This just in..."CLICK..."At this time there is no explina..." CLICK. I don't know about you, but even after doing a double shift, bites like THAT (pun INTENDED) catch my attention. Also, there was the missing of the Special Report bulletin while in the shower with her husband.

Another thing I wasn't feeling was "How" the dead were able to come back.

A proper tweak here, an added 15 to 20 minutes there (I believe the running time was close to an hour and a half) and you would have had a flawless thriller!!

I'd say the scariest thing about the movie (other than the grizzly, bloody, sprinting dead chasing you) was, again, the almost mindless, unquestioning acceptance of their situation.

The original Dawn was lauded for it's social satire and commercialism.

This comes into play in the remake for our current times as well. After all, when your government can effectively compromise one of it's 50 state's (FL) Presidential ballot and then pull a "You didn't see that" after a couple of "Hurumpfs" from the people and lull the masses back to sleep with business as usaul.....Survivor/Making Of The Band/The Internet/New Games/New Videos/New Music/New Controversy/New and better commercials to sell all of this and more PLUS The Rat Race in general....

Why question "Why" the dead coming back to life?

title: Very Good, But Not Great...
review:
Given the amount of dreck we horror fans have been forced to endure over the last ten years or so, it is refreshing to see some new life being pumped into the genre. Last year's remake of TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE was an excellent re-imagining of the story (although producer Michael Bay's heavy handed influence was quite prevalent), and now we have the remake of George Romero's classic DAWN OF THE DEAD.

Is the new version good? Yes, it is. I enjoyed it immensely (although I'm kicking myself for not staying through the closing credits as I normally do). Does it surpass the original? Not by a long shot.

The 1979 DAWN was a cleverly written, darkly foreboding, and bitingly satirical look at the human condition. There was a sense of dread that permeated the whole film, and you just found yourself wondering when the proverbial feces would hit the fan. In addition, sub-level social commentary on everything from consumerism to abortion could be found; the original DAWN OF THE DEAD was that most elusive of creatures...the intelligent horror film.

Now the new DAWN is certainly a thrill ride, and I wasn't as put off by the running zombies as I thought I would be. I just thought everybody accepted the end of the world a little too easily, and there were too many characters to flesh out in the film's 1 hr and 40 minute running time. And I'll admit, I'm not much for a lot of humor in these films; if you're gonna be dark, for crying out loud be DARK. If I want comedy, I'll watch ANIMAL HOUSE.

DAWN OF THE DEAD 2004 is certainly a legitimate addition to Romero's Living Dead canon (much like the excellent 1990 remake of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD), but I have a feeling I'll be sticking to my DVD of the original (gonna go watch it now, as a matter of fact!)

My rating: 7 1/2 out of 10....

title: Awesome Movie, Great Plot
review:
In My view of this movie, I really enjoyed it. I enjoyed the overall nature of the film from start to finish. *PLEASE NOTE* STAY FOR ENTIRE FILM, WHEN CREDITS COME ON, DO NOT LEAVE, THEY SHOW WHAT HAPPENS TO THEM ON THE ADVENTURE ON THE ITEM* Don't want to tell the film away but stay until the credits start rolling.

In the end, the film was realistic on some points in it and some it wasn't. The film has a view scenes that would make you jump out of your seat and some that were predicted but the film overall, had action, killing and was a great flick. For such a low Budget film at 28 mil, they made a great film (strike) did. It is a must see!! I also heard it ranked in 40 mil + and only cost 28 mil to make, means to me, that alot of people are going to see it and you should to!!

title: A bit disappointing, but well done nonetheless.
review:
#spoilers# Remakes are never as good as the original. Why should this be any different? The new Dawn was, and this was no shocker, disappointing.

There were too many characters, and no originality in any of them. In the original Dawn, there are four main characters, and they each have positive and negative recognizable traits. In this new Dawn, believe it or not, I now have trouble even rememberings what happened to who. There were just too many people held up in the mall. I'm not talking like 6. Im talking like 15. The script seemed to be just throwing characters in to have more deaths. The original Dawn had four characters, and only 2 of the 4 (if i remember correctly) survive. In this movie, well nevermind I shouldn't give away the ending. Also, the characters get to the mall way too quickly. The characters didn't stumble upon a landing space like in the original, one of them goes, "We're going to the mall." Then, they're their. Also, some of the sequences of the characters held up in the mall dragged on. However, the original put aside, this movie had some good gory action, awesome looking zombie, and the one thing they seemed to overlook in the original: CHAINSAWS!!! Hopefully the dvd will have some extra deleted gore scenes. Obviously they couldn't top the gore of the original and still maintain an R raiting. Finally, they made a stupid idea by showing the conclusion of the film in bits and pieces during the credits, so only the few people who actually sat through the credits and didn't leave got to see the "official" ending.

So, if you go see this, sit through all the credits! All in all, some points off for making it boring at times, and eliminating stuff from the original. Points on for action, gore, cool zombies, and chainsaw action.

Okay, there were actually some pretty creative ideas. Oh yeah and it wasn't scary either. I give it 6 out of 10. ..

title: Headshots & Chainsaws...necessary.
review:
Just after seeing Dawn of the Dead, I was left in shock and giddy postcoital glee. Man, I had SEEN a zombie movie. You know what, I had seen a damn good movie.

After 5 minutes of establishing the normalcy of the Wisconsin suburbs, we get the initial attack, which starts out with a scene more akin to the original zombie film Night of the Living Dead, then goes into mass destructionland via the last string of disaster movies.

The opening credits are the most powerful set of titles I've ever seen in a film. Scored to Johnny Cash's "When the Man Comes Around", they evoke feelings of genuine megadeth and apocalypse. I was reminded of watching the planes crashing into the WTC on 9-11. In fact, this is one of the first films that you will actually want to watch every second.

The plot picks up from there with the heroine escaping/meeting a weird cross-section of Americans en route to the refuge of the mall. Here, they escape the devastation momentarily through the trappings of the mall. These genuinely comic scenes alleviate the near-constant tension in DOTD. The plot picks up and gets more horrific, in a similar fashion to the original. Blah, blah--you know this part, so I'll skip it. I will say that the people in this movie are more sensible than in other zombie movies where they run around helpless to get eaten. The survivors, more or less, have survived for a reason--the ability to turn off their emotions and kill coldly.

The film as a whole was shatteringly powerful. The ricketing force of the whole package was overwhelming. This is the first horror film to update the genre to the level of style of other serious films from the 2000's. Forget that it is a remake; the plot is lifted, but the tone and visual style are totally original. In fact, this may be the most original film I've seen since Being John Malkovich. It seemed that, after the Texas Chainsaw remake and a slew of cruddy gore films with heavy metal soundtracks, the whole Gen X (or Y or whatever) attitude would never translate successfully into anyone's films beside Quentin Tarantino. Then, blam, here it is.

The handheld camera effects, believable characterizations, MTV editing, and overwhelming tone of nihilistic humor actually come together in this film. Gone are the 4th-barrier breaking self-references of the Scream generation, thank God. I was starting to think that the next trend in horror movies would be a l√° The Ring: a revisionism of the golden era of horror cinema that would be serious and slow-paced. I'm glad I was wrong. Here, the director uses all the latest tricks to actually further the impact of the material. He also mocks his characters with the playful smile of doom. Nevertheless, the tension pervades the attitude; we care about these people because they seem real. In a word: ensnaring.

Say goodbye to the schlock of yesterday, ladies and gentlemen, we have evolved.

title: Thanks, Gunn
review: I just saw this movie tonight, and in my opinion, is the best horror movie I have seen in 10 years. The acting from all involved seemed appropriate. The timing in the movie was excellent. It started out with some tense moments in a hospital then moved straight to a pretty intense, fast moving introduction until they got to the mall. Then the action kept up almost to the point where I would have been ready for it to stop, but then it started focusing more on the interactions of a very diverse crowd in a very stressful situation. This went on long enough until I was ready to be scared again, and they pulled it off. Admittedly you have to let yourself be scared by this movie, but if you are like me, you watch these movies just hoping that there will be more than one time that you at least jump a little, and they pulled that off for me. There was also some nice humor scattered throughout, some truly disturbing moments, just an experience overall. Anyway, this might not be as good as the original (I finally found a place to rent it, will watch that this week), but considering that they did not rely soley on special effects and gore to scare you (in fact, they didnt try at all, there was good use of moments where you expect something but you just arent entirely sure what). I'd say this is the best attempt at a horror movie since the 70's. Somebody here really had a grasp at what horror is really about and I'm glad.

title: This was definetly not a remake....
review:
I don't care what anybody says, this movie was not a remake. The only thing the new Dawn has in common with the original is the fact that it is a zombie movie that is set in a shopping mall at one point. Romero, however, used the shopping mall as a means of creating a social satire while Snyder on the other hand seemed to use the shopping mall location simply so he could stamp the name "Dawn of the Dead" on his piece of celluoid to increase fan base and profits.

Now despite my gripe with it being labeled a remake, I still found the film to be fairly enjoyable. It was a very slick blood and guts horror movie but tastefully done. I was a little dissapointed with the character development though. In the original Dawn, we are introduced to the four primary characters within the first fifteen minutes and find ourselves spending personal, intimate moments with them as they struggle with themselves and the elements for the next two hours. In the remake there were just too many characters for me to become attached to any particular one and consequently, I found myself not caring whether many of them lived or died.

One advantage the "remake" had over the original was the fantastic special effects. The zombies in the "remake" were very believable and terrifying while in original they were simply people with blue face paint on. This brings me to my next point - the running zombies. All I can say to that is - not cool Snyder, not cool.

title: Very happy!
review: I saw this film tonight and was happy as can be! We went to the early, cheaper showing just in case it was gonna be a stinker. But this film is no stinker! A good time was had by all! We ate popcorn,yelped,jumped talked back to the film "arrggh! No! what are you? Stupid?!!", laughed and screamed once or twice. The zombies looked "good", the people were "real" enough for me and there was a dog(I was hoping there would be a mall puppy mill/pet store, with puppies that the people would have to consider as a food source and of course the "good" people would not eat puppies. Or would they??!! Hee hee) This film was fully worth the $6.50 we each paid to see it. Maybe it's not a huge classic, but it WAS FUN! I give it a big 7. And please Lord...if I get caught in the middle of a zombie plauge...Let them be the slow zombies!!!....PLLEeease!!! :)

title: This movie has it all!!
review: This is one of the best flicks I have seen in a while. I can't think of one bad thing to say about it. I mean it was a little weird that the zombies could run and stuff but it didn't take long to get used to. Plus it takes away your comfort zone, in that, you can't think to yourself, `I would just run away from them.' because those mo-fos' are fast! Great acting, great characters,realistic gore, unbelievable suspense and I don't know what I would have done without the comic relief.  Another thing I liked was they weren't afraid to show you some guts. I mean, they weren't wusses about it. They didn't cut away from the really nasty stuff. This was one of those movies where the entire audience jumps, laughs and says, `What are you doing? Don't kiss her!! She's gunna bite you!!' all in unison. Oh and let's not forget that one girl sitting behind you, who screams her head off every time something happens. This one gets an easy 10 out of 10.

title: A good movie, but not worthy of the title.
review:
Let's get something straight here... the only thing this movie has in common with the original Romero classic, besides the title, is "mall" and "zombies". Everything else is different. The characters are different, the situations are different, even the zombies are different. I'm not saying this is a bad movie in any respect, I'm just saying that it deserved a different title. It's already a mostly-original movie, so why spoil a classic by naming it the same? Just because of the mall and zombies? If that were true, then shouldn't "Star Wars" be called "Star Trek" instead? They both have spaceships and aliens...

It's the zombie difference that strikes me the most... speedy zombies like the ones in this film seem to be today's "thing" in movies, but I think it just alters the kind of horror we're expecting from a zombie movie. Fast zombies give a SHOCK and SURPRISE kind of horror, while the original slow zombies bring a lot more tension and cold fear. Gone are things such as being injured and backed into a corner, and watching the zombies slowly converging on your position, knowing that the inevitable will happen. If the same situation happened in this movie, it'd be over in a second or two; the zombies would run up to you, and it's done. Where's the creepiness there? It's replaced by suddenness. Maybe it's me, but I'm more creeped out by a zombie slowly coming into view from the end of a hall and shuffling towards me slowly, rather than the same zombie suddenly charging out of the darkness at full speed. It's all about atmosphere and scaring people through actual terror rather than through 'make you jump out of your seat' action.

I still think it was a good movie. I just would have been happier if they hadn't tried to make it something it isn't: a remake of Dawn of the Dead.

title: re-make done right
review: ****Possible Spoilers**** I had the pleasure of driving past the Monroeville Mall just after watching the Re-Make of Dawn of the Dead...(which for diehards is where the first movie was filmed)...But anyways I would have to say I loved this movie, Sure the characters weren't as developed as the orginal but this one was more fast paced and too the point.  I liked the effect of having the more people inside that mall which lead to more people being picked off one by one. The gore was done right with just enough head shots and to say head impalings to go around.  The chainsaw on the bus was pretty cool idea too and to people that have seen know what happens with said chainsaw!!! The celebrity shooting game also made me laugh out loud. My only real problem is with the ending. Which is cool in it's own but could have been a bit more clearer, hey I'm a guy that likes closure so sue me. I just hope that this movie will inspire Romero to make a fourth film or for Zack to make another sequel. But overall I think people should just sit back and enjoy a great zombie movie with plenty splats and shocks..

title: Scary as HELL
review: This movie was awesome. It scared the bejesus out of me as times. I am a fan of Romero's movies and a fan of horror movies. To me this movie didn't feel like a remake, it felt more like a reimagining. The opening sequence sucked me right in. I prefer zombies to be slow and stupid, but if "28 Days Later" was a reinvention of zombie horror, then i guess having the zombies be fast in this movie is a good follow up on that concept. Survival horror movies rule!  I loved the Jay Leno zombie part that was hilarious. The soundtrack was great too. I liked the version of Disturbed's "Down with the Sickness" not done by them- but as like a swing/jazzy kind of song. I hope the DVD has a lot of deleted scenes. If you liked "The Passion of the Christ", go see this movie.

title: Classic!
review:
First, let me say, as one of the FEW die-hard fans of the original who decided it was better to live with his mind OPEN instead of CLOSED, I embraced the idea of something *different* when I heard about this remake. For your own sake, whether you have seen this film or not, you should too. DAWN OF THE DEAD is a great experience in horror movie-going, and this film really deserves to be viewed with a scared audience in a theater.

Don't be afraid...DAWN 04 not only does justice to its namesake, it becomes its own film entirely while never forgetting its roots. It borrows masterfully from elements of 28 Days Later but doesn't take itself too seriousley (as that film, though also great in its own right, did). The plot is very clever, fast-paced and original; never have I seen "zombies" handled quite like this. James Gunn, unlikely scribe of DAWN 04 (I say unlikely because he's responsible for the so-so SCOOBY DOO film and is also a TROMA alumnus), knows how to do zombies -- he nails the action in a way every fan of the undead dreams of. The pacing is breakneck-quick, but not to DAWN's detriment; you are never allowed to feel safe or get comfortable. In this case, that's a good thing -- you are constantly on your toes and biting your nails.

Technically speaking, I'm not a big fan of claustrophobic closeups, and although this film has its share, it's not that distracting and it's more than made up for in the excellent camera work. Some may be reminded of SAVING PRIVATE RYAN; there is almost a documentary feel in certain scenes. The visual work in DAWN OF THE DEAD underscores the film's intended atmosphere perfectly -- you are almost thrown into the action.

Some in internet gripe circles (heh, as if there's any other type of "circle" on the internet) have complained a bit about the "lack" of character development due to the large cast, but I could find no real cause for that here. True, DAWN 04 is not the social allegory, nor the drama that its namesake was, but it doesn't pretend to be what it's not. It also doesn't pretend that it wants us to get to know every single character introduced; the leads make themselves known, and the script "develops" them appropriately in the parameters of the kind of film that this is. There is indeed a good human element in this script -- not heavy handed, gooey or predictable, but just right for the film.

The cast is well-picked, and the acting top-notch -- there were a few really memorable performances here (most notably in the characters of "CJ" and "Steve"), as well as a few hearty laughs thrown in for balance, but once again you never feel safe. The humans make fun of the marauding dead in the parking lot below the mall, but it merely serves to make the sense of morbidity, human mortality and fear stronger; we know they're only out for a nervous laugh to forget their miserable situations. Again, the human element is handled well for such a horror film. Kudos to James Gunn.

DAWN OF THE DEAD isn't perfect, but you'll be so busy hanging on to your seat, laughing and screaming that you won't notice.

Go see it.

title: Great Movie
review:
I'm at least a moderate fan of horror flicks, although not quite as avid as some of these zombie fanatics :) Coming at this more from a neutral standpoint, I must say this movie has all the elements: suspense/drama, gore, character development, mostly superb acting, great cinematography... the movie kept me captivated throughout, and you actually sympathize with the protagonists. Very fast paced, always keeps you on your toes and a few curve balls are thrown. Perhaps the plot is lacking a bit, but really this is a superb movie.

Overall I'd give this movie an A-; see it in the movie theatres!

title: I LOVE THIS MOVIE!!!!!
review:
I just got back from the theatre and i have to say this movie ROCKS!!!!

I loved the original and i was very sceptical about the remake because i didnt think you could improve on an almost perfect movie but man was i wrong-I have only one complaint and it involves a small infant but i wont say a whole lot for those of you who have not seen the movie.

the casting was perfect...Ving Rhames,Sarah Polly they were meant to play those parts and they were even able to include cameos from Scott,Ken and Tom(who btw had the best line of the movie!)

The makeup was not overdone and the special effects were outstanding-I think this is the version Romero might have wanted the first time because he said in his commentary of the original film the he wanted more zombies and there were a ton of them in this film.

Some people criticize the film saying you dont need running zombies but i felt they were done very well-if you were hungry and was starving for food i believe you would run for it also.

I felt for these characters even the not so nice ones and I think that helps make a great film-you feel sorry for the not so lucky ones and cheer for the unlikly heroes and feel the suspence in a dire situation.

A very good movie and i can't wait to see this again.

Ty

title: One of the Greats
review: This remake is probably the best remake of all time.  The director captured everything that Romero put into the original, and added some more.  The character's are realistic, unlike those in some horror movies, and the special effects are captivating.  The comic relief bits are funny, and give you a sense of security, when you already know there is none.  But we definitely have to thank the movie "28 days later."  If not for that excellent film, "Dawn of the Dead" would not have been anywhere near as exciting as it was.  I know most of you are true fans of George Romero, as I am one myself, but this movie does not knock his name from the top; it raises it higher.  I don't know about anyone else, but I give this movie a BIG 10, and will be back in the theaters very soon!!!

title: Short version: I had fun.
review:
Long version: (no spoilers...I double checked)

I am more annoyed at the theatre company for bringing up the house lights over the credits (stay, by the way) than I am at the movie executives who greenlighted this project who had all "made the list" when I heard this mulligan was being filmed.

While I hope that Romero, Savini and all the other original cast members who made cameos were well paid for their time, I have to say that the new group of beseiged castaways did an okay job of making the idea of being holed up in a shopping mall surrounded by the flesh eating undead their own.

Okay...I still have a problem with the 28 Days Later style of agile and quick moving zombies. I am a traditionalist. But it was obvious that a significant portion of of screen writer James Gunn's misspent youth involved an immersion in the classics of the genre, and a whole lot of video games. So the material is treated with reverence, respect, pathos, and the right amount of jet black humour to ensure that I did not feel violated, or even cheated out of my money. (Except for the house lights thing which REALLY annoyed me!)

The movie is quite artfully crafted and filled with visual allusions to the entire original trilogy. The gore is pervasive and squishy without being overwhelming or too comical, and your first calls about who lives and who dies are probably going to be right on the money.

There are no suprises here, and it breaks no new ground in the genre, but the individual elements combine well to create an overall satisfying zombie stomp.

title: Great modern day horror flick. The original 'Dawn' is of course better. But this one delivers a great plot like the original.
review:
I saw this movie with my mother and my sister at 6:45 Eastern Time. I'm a die hard fan of Romero's 'Dead" Trilogy and am still very skeptical about this movie. However, it's one of the best horror films in years along with titles like 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre', 'The Ring', and for longtime fans of horror movies 'Freddy vs. Jason'. I might add that 'Jason X' was one of the worst in years. But it feels good that they're bringing back the classics and not ruining them as we've seen in years past.

The opening scene of the 2004 re-make of 'Dawn' is a great way to get your audience involved with a movie. The gore, the athlete fast zombies, and some disturbing images are a good way to get this movie going. The make-up was outstanding and the 'twitching' zombies were pretty cool. Seeing Ken Foree, Scott Reiniger, and Tom Savini in the movie were a thrill of its own. However, they only had 20 seconds each in the film. I believe they should have been involved a little bit more in the movie.

The acting overall was great. Ving Rhames delivers a kick-ass performance. More characters were in this movie to make it seen on many different point of views. The gore is alright but the DVD should give us some guts getting teared out of a biker. Oh, no only that graphic could be on the original 'Dawn'. But this movie is great on a different level and is guaranteed to be worth seeing once, twice, or a few times. I think it was better than 28 Days Later. 'Dead' fans already started running to the theater. ** 3/4 out of 4.

title: More babes, redder blood
review:
George Romero's "Dawn of the Dead" has been a favourite of mine since I first saw it, in a heavily censored version, in Toronto in 1978/79.

I eventually saw the uncut version on video, courtesy of my older brother, who snagged the REAL version from a US video store; the frenetic pacing, cool special effects, nifty music & the STORY of the original "Dawn" all impressed me no end, and the film is easily in my Top Ten favourite films of all time.

I was dismayed when I heard about the remake, but, after seeing it this afternoon, I can say that I quite liked it, even if it is not as effective as the original, but it is a movie that reflects the time(s), and I think that it is not the travesty that I thought that it'd be.

First time director Zack Snyder does a good job, although some of his "tricks" are a bit obvious, and I think that there is perhaps too much blood, and the ghastly "thrash" metal on the soundtrack had my ears perilously close to bleeding (that said, the use of a certain Jim Carroll Band tune over the end credits is inspired).

The new "Dawn" takes the original "survivors of a zombie apocalypse holed-up in a shopping mall" (Toronto's Thorncliffe Mall), and expands upon it, adding more survivors than the original had; also, it has to be noted that the cast of the new "Dawn" is top-heavy with fabulous babes, notably the lovely & talented Sarah Polley, who plays an ass-kicking nurse with much aplomb.

Other babe-a-licious cast members include Lindy Booth, Inna Korobkina, and Kim Poirer, all of whom will probably be seen sporting bikinis in the pages of "Maxim" any day now.

The guys in the film all fair pretty well, too; Ving Rhames is as solid as ever, and Jake Weber, Mekhi Phifer, and especially Michael Kelly as the p***ed off mall security guard, are all splendid.

The fact that the zombies in the new version are considerably faster than the slow-moving ghouls of the past owes more than a little to the speedy living dead of Danny Boyle's "28 Days Later".

To sum up, the new "Dawn of the Dead" is pretty decent, and has babes to spare, but for a more thoughtful (and more fun) time, buy the original.

title: Well, it didn't suck.
review:
I'll give it a 7 out of 10. I was expecting total crap and was pleasantly surprised by the films wit and brutality. I do think much was lost in the rapid fire editing ala Blackhawk Down ... while this gave the movie a more frantic pace, it made you wonder what the hell you were looking at during much of the carnage.

I only wish they had come back to the Monroeville Mall (site of the first DAWN) so I could have auditioned to be an extra. Oh well, another chance at immortality dashed!

The soundtrack deserves special mention. The use of the late Johnny Cash's "When The Man Comes Around" was a flash of pure brilliance.

title: Better than I expected
review: This remake was better than I expected. The only major complaint I have is that there is a little too much comic relief, but otherwise this is a fine addition to the "Dead" world. I hope that it makes mega bucks, so that hopefully George Romero can get the financial backing to make a top-notch fourth and final film in his original series. The special effects and zombies are well done, the quality of acting is far above any found in most zombie films, and it is not overly gory. It will be interesting to see what deleted scenes will be added back in the DVD version of the film. Some purist fans of the original Romero version will probably be full of complaints about this movie, but I say to them ,the original version was not a perfect film by any means either, so give this one a chance, I think it will grow on you.

title: STFU
review:
Anyone who doesn't think this movie deserves a very strong ten out of ten needs to have a screwdriver worked into their ear.

I loved the originals, but Romero is, at best, a schlock director. Savini's remake of Night of the Living Dead was better than all three of Romero's, and Romero would have been nothing without Savini.

This new movie grabbed me from the beginning, and worked me hard. There were plot holes big enough to throw a zombie baby through, but who cares? I got my moneys worth, and I can't wait for the next one. I agree with everything positive the above commenters have said, and then some.

This silly thing wants me to be wordy, and have at least ten lines, so I'll just say that if I had been the character in the gun shop, the movie would have ended a lot differently. And I do tire of the standard "Charlie, go check the horses" cliche where some shlub(s) go off into the dark to see if they can be killed like Star Trek Red Shirts.

Nevertheless, this was a movie that, if the Oscars weren't such a sad joke, would be a worthy contender for the camera work, if naught else.

title: WAIT TILL THE CREDITS ARE COMPLETELY DONE BEFORE YOU LEAVE!!
review: One of the best zombie movies in a long time...okay, probably the best one I've ever seen.  Good character development even!  It was gory, but the kind that makes you go 'ewwwww'...not yuck.  Had the needed 'what a jerk' kind of guy that you loved to hate.  Had a few funny moments.  Had it's fair share of jump out of your seat moments.  And, had a ton of 'Get your butt out of there' scenes too.  If you enjoy this sort of film, go see it.  You'll not be disappointed!  But, and this is a huge but, DON'T LEAVE UNTIL THE CREDITS ARE COMPLETELY FINISHED. The aisles were full of people who started to leave when the credits started to roll...AND IT'S NOT OVER!!  So go, enjoy, and stay seated till the lights come on!

title: lots of action, baby
review:
this movie has lots if action, from beginning to end, u must stay past the credits,and watch what happens. all the characters were cool, i liked the chainsaw part towards the end

that was just sick and cool. ving rhames was ok, sara polley could of been better, but the guy who played c.j. was a real badass, i liked him. and whats with the dog, if i was a zombie, i would of bit him, a dog is a warm blooded and has flesh just like humans.the part with the baby was stupid, and a street thug living in wisconsin, dating a russian chick, and there was a huge amount of zombies in this movie,which is awsome.but overall, the movie was pretty good

title: Warning -Spoilers- Warning
review:
Ok, I just saw the remake of DOTD. It really scared the @#$@ out of me, I liked it. But, Because I have to do it, here is what I didn't like.

1. I think it makes sense that zombies might move fast. The problem is that not ALL zombies should move fast. The fat lady for example, you'd think she'd be a bit slower than the rest. Also, after they start to decay for a while (or go awhile without "food") you'd think they'd start to slow down a bit.

2. Zombie bites, even little ones that barely leave a mark always kill you and turn you into a zombie. This tends to say that there was a virus of some sort that causes the phenomenon (28 Days Later). If this is the case, then it would not have happened suddenly without warning in a single day AROUND THE WORLD. Also, if the only way to become a zombie is to be bitten by one, where did the first zombie come from? On top of that, what about the cop with the cut on his arm. He got zombie blood in that cut, so why didn't he become zombified?

3. This one goes along with number 2. People in this movie died in normal ways (gunshots, chainsaws, etc) In the original, those people would have become zombies. In this one, they stayed down. This adds to a less realistic (if there is such a thing) zombie movie.

4. If I knew that the world had been taken over by zombies, and I was coming up to an island, would I just come ashore and hang out? No, I'd circle the island in the boat, and make lots of noise, to attact zombies. If none came after several hours, then I'd come ashore. If zombies did show up, I'd leave.

5. Zombies don't like to eat dogs. Why would a zombie care if you were a human or a dog. It knows that you are warm living flesh. It would eat the dog!!

6. Isn't it convenient that Anna crashed her car right next door to the mall?

7. When he first shows up, CJ is a very unlikeable person. He is ready to kill everyone else to insure his survival. They even have to lock him up because of this. Then, very suddenly, near the end, he decides that he'd rather stay behind in the van, to act as a diversion. He ultimatly blows himself up so that the others might live. How Christ like of him!!

8. When Anna and Louis were in the shower, the TV shows a special news bulletin. Though we do not actually see this bulletin, we assume it is about the zombies. One would think that this would be all over the news once the story broke. So when they got out of the shower, somebody had to turn the tv off. They probably notice then that the news was reporting about zombies.

9. In the first 30 seconds of the movie, they talk about a patient who had a bite on his hand, and then had to be sent to the ER. HE WAS A ZOMBIE!! Anna works in a hospital, the zombie had been there all day long. He would have started attacking people by then! Anna would already know about the zombies!!! She is a smart girl!

10. In the mall parking lot, there was hundreds if not thousands of zombies. But just one block away the streets were empty. Why?

Anyways I'm done with my rant. Thanks!!!

title: um... word.
review:
*spoilers as hell*

ya know its really tempting to sit back and just be negative about something and take a cynical approach, but in fact that is really just a shallow, easy way out.

that having been said, this movie sucked.

are the security guards supposed to replace my beloved bikers? is cj blades? there is no tension there, they kiss and make up out of survival? sure thats a great new message for a peaceful tomorrow, but hey, it also sucks. this is a horror movie, damn it.

i dont mind new characters coming in left and right, but only if they serve a purpose other than to just give an excuse for another special make-up effect. bringing someone in just as exit wound eye candy is a waste, and only further adds to a feeling of randomness. to say the tension between classes is a underlying theme is a far stretch, so there is a rich guy thats a prick to everyone... just give them their oscar now.

fast zombies i dont mind, there is still a good tension build up, maybe even more intense than the zombies of ol'. andy i didnt mind either, again a nice improv. the flesh tear in the begining that mimics the 78 is nice, as is the plotting to get supplies through the zombies. all great, just loved it. i didnt love the emphasis on guns rather than their target, and i didnt like explosions every 5 (ok, 15) seconds. forget ving, get arnold in this piece and call it predator 3, with special guest appearances from sex and wish-i-were-knb fx.

all that out of the way, the title sequence is one of my favorites of all time, the man comes around over some delicious images and well done distressed type. absolutely stunning, no jokes about it, i'm almost tempted to go see it again just for that.

title: It's questionable as to whether its a remake or not, but it's the best zombie film since 1992
review: As a long time fan of zombie films (as well as all horror films) I can honestly say I am impressed.  28 Days Later?  I loved it.  It was a tribute to the George Romero films (watch it, you'll see it).  I don't think that one measured up to Dawn though.  The completely rehashed story and characters was a fresh breath of air to we, the fans of zombie flicks. The characters were more or less real, the plot and how the characters reacted to the events was believeable, and the gore was perfect.  As far as gore goes, it finally broke the trend of using a cut away as opposed to old fashioned Savini-esque effects.  Ok, so I don't sound like I am some starry eyed fan who saw no flaws in it, I did think that some things that happened were...shall we say forced...(The baby thing...)  But coming from somone who has seen them all, I'd easily say this is the best zombie flick since 1992's Peter Jackson (thats right kids) Directed DEAD/ALIVE.  On a scale from 1-10, this one is a 10.

title: zombie movies are freaky... THE END!
review: i really liked this movie. i love horror movies, but zombie movies are the ones that scare me the most since dead people should stay dead! i haven't seen any good horror movies lately, so this is awesome. i like the fact that they go straight to the point: like, less than 10 minutes into the movie, hell breaks loose! and i also like the fact that they continue showing scenes during the credits since i hate it when we don't get to see the ending-ending in a lot of movies. the only things is, it didn't seem that believable: the whole running super speed/strength zombies. but it did make the movie freakier. there is one scene that i can't stop thinking about and it's the one with the dog and the sandwich going to andy, i was freaked since i'm a big dog fan. well, all i have to say is that you should watch it since i'm sure there won't be a really good horror movie coming out anytime soon!

title: Cracks of Dawn: The original has nothing to worry about..
review: I enjoy zombie-plague apocalypse movies, I don't know why.  Maybe my therapist could tell me.  I'll see just about anything that features the walking dead, or in this case, sprinting dead.  The gold standard for this genre is obviously the Romero trilogy.  While I enjoyed aspects of the DOTD update, it was pretty clear that this was a studio cash grab.  Why even use the DAWN title when this would have been more aptly titled Resident Evil Goes Shopping?  Because they know we'll show up to the theaters like the mindless flesh-eaters to the mall. Possible spoilers ahead.  There is interesting new cemetery ground broken here; Re-animated fetus storyline, different escape/rescue scenarios, Chilling CGI enhanced scenes of what appear to be thousands of the undead in the streets.  On the plus side: Cool Johnny Cash song about death over credit montage of chaotic news clips builds a sense of dread.  Strong opening, it grabs you.  It certainly doesn't waste any time getting the characters to the mall.  The acting is strong among the main cast.  Zombie make-up very impressive.  Negatives include fancy MTV/Private Ryan camera work that makes the action hard to decipher at crucial times.  Too many characters/weak characterization.  Running zombies?  Pretty co-ordinated for something just revived from the dead.  I prefer my zombies retarded and limping across the parking lot.  Gore is rather subdued, nothing's shocking. An insulting storyline involving a dog named "Chips" (groan).  Cliched hero sacrifices himself for the greater good bit.  "You go on, I'll catch up...arghhh!!" Blechhh.  6 out of 10.  It can be entertaining at times and while I do recommend it to zombie fans, it will just make you appreciate the original more and hey, that's not a bad thing.  "We whupped 'em and we got it all!!!"

title: faster and scarier by miles leaps and bounds.....
review:
the zombies do that too by the way. this dawn was going to be a 1 in a million shot. it would either be #1: another hollywood remake that brings in the bucks, but leaves out the entertainment. or #2: a fast frantic ride thru hell with very little room for it's characters and story. well it's #1 and #2 in a nice neat little package that IS another hollywood remake and it WILL bring in the bucks, but the entertainment is not only there but it often times feels so pressed in upon you that you have to crouch in your'e seat and just surrender to it. and #2 it IS a VERY fast and frantic ride thru hell but it actually seems to - be prepared to gasp - CARE FOR SOME OF IT'S CHARACTERS! the story is the same as it was in the original but this go-round we get to see it happen from the very beginning, the onslaught of what's to come.

*but be warned this is a blood-soaked movie from 3 minutes in, to the last name in the credits* grade A entertainment!!!

title: Surprisingly Good and Fun
review:
Great film. Just as good as the original but for different reasons. You can never remake a film, so this re-imagining rocked. This isn't the 70s, something needed to change. After 30 yrs of zombie films some things had to change, and it worked. people aren't going to react the same to Zombies as they would in the 70s. If a some stumbling slow zombie came running towards you, I am sure a 12yo would know what to do. The film had to change some things to make a Zombie film frightening in modern day.

Also a loved the strong female heroine. The chick in the last one was so weak and annoying. This film benefited with the new idea of the kick butt chick, who does what she needs to do to survive. It also has intentional humor in it, something old horror fans will aprreciate. It was just a rocking good time. As far as scariness they did as much as they could with a R rating. Got away with some gross stuff too and a few good scares.

The characters, and acting was really amazing. The acting in the original was HORRIBLE. So I'd say the the two films are equally good for different reasons.

Also stay for the credits, there you will see the true ending. Whomever doesn't like the ending didn't stay for the credits.

title: Fantastic and very well done!!!
review:
Its very simple, take that artsy piece of foreign crap: "28 Days Later" and wipe your A55 with it! becuase the "Dawn of The Dead" remake is the real deal. Directors Paul Anderson (Resident Evil) and the awful Danny Boyle (28 Days Later) should really use "Dawn of The Dead" to get a clue about how a zombie film is done correctly.

Dawn of The Dead has all the action and survival horror that anyone could want in a zombie movie and it sticks to the simple basics. The casting is also fantastic, Ving Rhames who plays a noble ex-marine turned cop is just the kind of bulldozer I would want watching my back when taking on the undead. Rather than Michelle Rodriguez (Res Evil) LOL or a skinny Britt running around with his shirt off (28 Days Later). "Dawn of The Dead" sets new standards of "doing things right" for present day hollywood. I give this film 3 out of 4 stars, its phenominal. Go out and buy the original also, the original Dawn and the remake are both equally well done.

title: A good movie but not at all scary
review: The movie is basically just like House of the dead! I won't bore you with a bunch of plot explaining, but i do love the action which is why I give this movie a ten!! it is really worth the 10 bucks for the ticket, its packed with blood and gore and a few emotional and funny scenes! I personally never saw the Romero original so i can't judge and compare the two but I do know that this movie is very good and will hopefully stay in the theaters for a while, this movie is a real "Popcorn muncher" There is nudity but it is at the end for about 2 seconds so for those who are worried about nudity its not packed with it like most horror movies. I really hope that you go and see this movie!

title: A surprisingly good remake!!!
review: I'm a big fan of horror movies, especially the original Dawn Of The Dead. So I was quite excited when I found out a remake was on it's way! Then I found out it was being made by first time director Zack Snyder. Disappointment started to set in at this point because I thought it would be a terrible remake (as they usually are). All this aside, I left the cinema pleasantly surprised! I was happy to see Ken Foree as the televangelist (from what I've read, there were several other cameos from the original cast too). To say it is a precise remake would be lying! There are a lot more characters taking refuge in the mall and the zombies are a lot more terrifying in that they are so much faster (think 28 Days Later). I especially appreciated the little nods to the original such as when the young girl bites the husband at the beginning, when it shows the flesh being torn out and still hanging from the young girls mouth! Stupidly gory but appreciated! This surpasses most modern day horror films and doesn't seem to stick to the same cliches said horror films stick to! This movie is well worth the admission price. So, if you want your horror films full of blood, guts and gore then go see! If you are a fan of the original then go see! Who knows, maybe this could be start of a zombie flick revival (28 Days Later, Dawn Of The Dead, Shaun Of The Dead).

title: Great zombie movie, modern-style
review:
This movie met all my expectations and more. From the trailer I know it's a movie with fast zombies instead of the slow ones from the original. That alone hooks me and draws me to the movie; I've never been able to get into the old "Dead" movies Romero did. I mean, come on, the zombies are so slow you can run circles around them. How scary is THAT?

I never watched the original Dawn of the Dead (only saw Night and Day), but I liked what I see here. Right of the bat, the action takes off 5 minutes into the movie. This movie isn't about panic, it's pure adrenaline packed into an hour and a half. The action is fast-paced and relentless, helped by the zombies that can probably run faster than you can.

And I just loved some of the irony in this movie, in moments it's deeper than most horror movies.

title: OMG!
review:
Well, I just got back from seeing this movie and am still in a bit of awe.I thought it was a great remake of a classic film. The storyline and jolts were evenly distributed throughout that film. The humour was placed at a perfect point. I loved when they shot the zombies and labled them as "Jay Leno" and "Burt Reynolds". I thought that was sooo great.

(SPOILERS)

I didn't like how the ending went through the credits.It didn't ruin the movie, but I sorta wish they would have kept going with the ending without the credits interrupting what happened next.

That was my short review. All together i really liked this movie and encourage those who like horror films to see this.

title: loved every bloodsplattered second
review:
drool! such a good movie! grr, i don't want to give any of it away, but i can hardly keep myself from spurting all its zombie goodness. i am yet to see the original, so i don't know how good the remake is in comparison. but as far as i'm concerned it was bloody awesome.

not your typical slow poking brain munching zombies, also not your typical american teens showing gratuitous amounts of flesh and making lots of sarcastic comments, which has been apparent in most of today's horror movies. and there was lots of gore. loads of it, and it was all fantastic! from crowbars to chainsaws, the lot! soundtrack kicked ass too. the characters were normal everyday folk, without being annoying stereotypes, and the comedy was present, but without being irritating pip and merry (lotr) style "comic" relief.

jodiejo likey, recommendy, and want to see the original-y

title: Great remake
review: As a fan of the original Romero films and the genre in general, I was somewhat apprehensive to see what this film would do with the material. Fortunately, the result was an onslaught of gore, awesome looking modern-day `fast' zombies, well honed homage to the past, and snippets of originality from the writer/director that make this a truly excellent addition to the zombie film collection!  While House of the Dead (last year) had its good moments (and its bad as well), Dawn exhibited quality filmmaking all the way through.  I really enjoyed the energy, visual effects (gore) and cinematography, and the characters in this movie.  So many horror movies these days forget that characters are as important as the rest of the action.  Not here.  If you are a zombie fan, and you enjoyed 28 Days and/or the original Living Dead movies, you really should see this movie on the big screen.  There are some really great suspense sconces that we could never have imagined back in the 1970s.   Enjoy!

title: Dawn gets a 9 out of 10
review: The new Dawn of the Dead movie is awesome. I plan to see it many times in the theater. It looks as if they mixed the original film with 28 Days Later. I fine mix if you ask me.I would give the movie 9 out of 10, only because of the baby scene and I know that there is approximately 10 minutes of footage that will appear on the dvd. Overall, anyone who remotely liked 28 Days Later or any of Romero's earlier zombie films will love this one. The scene where they were picking off zombies that looked like celebrities was a good break in the horror. It was funny in a demented sort of way. The ending that extended through the credits was a little darker than the original. I definately recommend this movie.

title: Deserves a Seat Among Zombie Greatness
review: I saw this film last night with a friend of mine. I absolutely loved it, but sitting there, knowing my friend was a stickler and elitist about such things, I wondered what he was thinking. After we left the theater (yes, and into a mall), I asked him his opinion and as par for the course, he went on to talk about how "As Dawn of The Dead had more 'stupid' action, 28 Days Later was superior because it was acted better, had a stronger plot, was tied together nicely at the end and was uplifting." If you ask me.. do you go to a zombie flick to feel uplifted? No! You want pure hell on earth. You want chaos, and to see how people react to that situation. I won't make fun of '28 Days' because there are fans of it out there, but I think that's a niche zombie film. Dawn of The Dead deserves a seat alongside the rest of Romero's Living Dead films as classic zombie fare. Also, what's the fun of a neat-and-clean ending? Zombies ARE hell on earth. You can't possibly stop it, if it were to happen. There would be no 'nice clean endings' except your own death, given that this was for real. I won't spoil anything, but you will be satisfied at the ending, if you want this world to continue for a possible sequel.. Yes, there are some cinematic licenses taken (such as when the girl goes to save her dog, Chips. Blatant stupid plot device), but if you consider it, rational thought WOULD escape you somewhat, if you were in this situation. The first few minutes of the film try to toss you into this world, and do so excellently.Camera work was innovative, and really tossed you into this chaotic world satisfyingly quick. I knew right before the credits were rolling at the start of the film, that I was in for an excellent time. I wasn't let down.  DotD definetely delivers pure action, solid acting, solid plot, excellent, 'bought' special effects, and well done tension. I personally loved how the screenwriters explored what else someone could do in such a world..how different people might react.. (overzealous, hick security guards from Wisconsin bieng one example,) This, I feel, is the second best zombie film i've seen, only rivaling Night of The Living Dead. The original 'Dawn' was far, far too slow, acting poor, and the social commentary, while commended, was not needed. Leave that to Sci-Fi films with apes in em, okay? I'm ready for Resident Evil Apocalypse now!

title: Enjoyed Most of This Film
review:
This film was very entertaining if you take it for what it is...a story about dead people taking over the planet. Fast-paced, creepy, well done effects, great acting, etc. If you want to break down the finer points, I have only two small complaints. First, not one character showed me the "what the hell is going on" panic mode that I think would be overtaking me in a situation like that. And the other-the shot that Mekhi Phifer's character took at Ving Rhames' character missed by a mile at point blank range while throughout the rest of the film most everyone was dead-on accurate.

I love horror films. I love horror films that keep your heart racing. This one does the trick for me. Wow, my wife even liked it and I had to talk her into going with me.

I think I may have seen the original when I was a little kid but don't remember it. I am now going to track it down on DVD just for comparitive reasons.

Solid 8/10.

title: A great zombie movie
review: I'm a very avid fan of zombie movies, and like any huge fan I am very familiar with the original Dawn of the Dead. It set the bar for apocalyptic zombie fests and contained a brain inside its gory exterior. The new Dawn doesn't have that. In fact, the new Dawn doesn't have anything that made the original so great... aside from the mall, of course. That doesn't make it a bad movie. If this movie were named something else, I wouldn't have a single complaint... I would be raving about how fantastic of a zombie movie this was. But they decided to have this as a remake of a Romero classic, and they ripped out everything that made the original so... original. The new Dawn is scary, visceral and fast paced. If they would have slowed it down, and stepped it back a bit so the viewers could get a chance to know the characters, and see the characters reaction to their situation it would have paid better homage to the original. They're different movies, and they are both great in their own right. The new Dawn is excellent in its own way, and in itself sets a new standard for zombie movies. Hopefully the zombie movie will stay around for a while. I would like to see how this sub-genre fleshes out. Only time will tell.

title: Zombies were never so much fun.
review: Though I haven't seen the original (but do intend to soon), I was drawn to this movie like the zombies to the mall.  The premise, people seeking refuge in a mall from a zombie epidemic, is a very intriguing one.  Normally, I'm not one for zombie films (The Romero's and the Raimi's being the exceptions).  But I found this to be a very entertaining film.  It is by no means scary or frightening, but it does have its share of creepy moments. Compared to 28 Days Later, this film seems to be going more for audience gratification, rather than the classiness of independent films.  In this aspect, Dawn of the Dead delivers time and again.  There's a great sequence involving celebrity look-alike zombies; though I won't ruin it for anyone. The movie's got a good sense of what it's trying to accomplish.  Director Zack Snyder and co. intend to bring George Romero's 1978 classic a modern touch, for a modern audience.  More often than not, the film works.  The plot (though altered) remains viable after 25 or so years.  Also, Dawn of the Dead has an excellent sense of humor.  Occasionally, the film seems to be mocking the whole concept of the end of the world.  Great action, great tunes (you ain't heard nothing 'til you've heard "Down With the Sickness" performed by a lounge singer), lots of fun.  I really enjoyed this film. 8/10.

title: Pleasantly Surprised!
review:
First off, I've been a fan of the original for years and I was extremely skeptical on what a remake would be able to achieve considering the source material. That being said, James Gunn and Zack Snyder have put together not only one of the best remakes of any film I have seen in years, but a true classic within the zombie genre itself. Is it as good as the original? It's hard for me to consider that since one of the things I love about the 1979 version is that it's so...well 1979! I couldn't expect a 2004 version to include a ultra low-budget effects department, Goblin soundtrack, and the Brown Derby Luv Pub. This version definitely has some elements of the Scream/I Know What You Did Last Summer generation of horror film-making, but for the most part it improves the movie rather than turning it into another post-1990 crapfest. There are enough sly nods to the original to demonstrate that Snyder is a fan of the cult classic, but he still makes sure to let the audience know that this his own masterpiece right from the opening scene. Most importantly, the film doesn't cop-out like last years 28 Days Later did. Snyder thankfully realizes that a movie about the apocalypse should stay true to it's theme from beginning to end. There are still a couple of minor flaws. The film does unfortunately shy away from the original's underlying message about consumerism, but that would be difficult to pull off in any film in 2004 since the film industry is now such integral part of that anyway. I also would have loved to hear the hilarious mall muzak that played during the 1979 version's closing credits, but Jim Carroll's People Who Died and Johnny Cash's Man Comes Around are fantastic replacements.

In the end, Dawn of the Dead 2004 is not only a film that should satisfy purists of the original classic, but also a refreshing revisit to the zombie genre that will hopefully inspire other filmmakers to do the same.

8/10

title: Toss up
review:
Okay, to get it out of the way, the original "Dawn" was better, no argument, end of story. But to look at this as an entirely different movie (which was incredibly difficult, but I always try to give a fair chance whenever I see a movie, especially a remake), but again as its own movie, the new "Dawn" wasn't that bad. It was immensely better than most of the new era zombie movies we've been dealing with like Resident Evil and House of the Dead, which were both based on video games and would have been 100 times better if they had let the actual video game creators write the script instead of giving us awful dialogue such as, "So what you're telling us it that we have to shoot them in the head?" Please, it sounds like an eighth grader wrote that.

Sorry. Anyway, what every horror movie needs in order to work is to build strong characterization so that we can feel what they're feeling and truly hope that nothing awful happens to them. For the new "Dawn" I honestly didn't care, most of the time I was silently saying, "Okay, let's drop some of these characters and get moving." Most of the people had no identities at all, such as the slutty blonde and the old man who was trying on the women's shoes. Do you remember their names? Didn't think so.

The only character that I truly had bad feelings for was Matt Frewer's character, "Frank." Solely because I love Matt Frewer and would not be able to bare seeing the man stub his toe. You don't want him to die, especially when they approach him to tell him he's infected, but he was busy talking to his daughter with a smile on his face. "No. . ." Is what I was saying.

The movie wasn't awful, it had some of those obligatory "zombie jumping out of nowhere and making you hop out of your chair a little bit, then you look around to see if anybody saw you do that." Otherwise, the film wasn't scary. It was the same formula; zombies run amok, a group of people unite and isolate themselves, something goes wrong, gotta get out of there, the black character lives. That wasn't a racist remark, it's just something I've noticed with zombie flicks.

title: Much better than I expected it to be
review:
First of all I am not even going to compare this re-make to the original because it is unfair to do that. if people wanted it to be like the original they would rent the original from 1978.

On its own Dawn Of The Dead stands out for the same reasons the original stood out. You see horror and gore unlike anything you've seen before. The wounds are realistic. You see brains fly from the zombies' heads. This movie was obvously intended not to hold any realism back. When someone in it, zombie or a human, are shot you see blood sputter and smear very realistically.

Besides the gore realism this movie succeeds at scaring me with genuine "pop out of your seat" scares. You know how some horror movies just scare you with some blood murder scene and leave you scared from disgust rather than from surprise. Dawn of The Dead director skillfully overcomes this and scares you when you least expect it. There are some scenes where everyone is happy and calm and you relax your nerves than a zombie jumps out and your pants suddenly get in danger of being pooped.

I could truly bond with some of the characters and feel their pain and fear. You see expressions on their faces change as they see people around them die and realize that their families are dead. I do think, however, that there wasnt much social commentary in this film, that is its just action action action. There is no pauses or change of pace for viewers or characters to behave differently and reflect somehow on what has happened and possibly see some conections with real world.

Cinematography in this one is not bad. I am not an expert on it, but I think in some scenes the color was too intense to portray feeling, everything looked cartoonishly bright. Then, especially in zombie attack and struggle, the camera was jerking around as if its some journalist filming in a riot. The camera was moved around so much it was hard to follow whats happening. Then the frame rate was reduced as well, probably to add more realism and to cover up the special effects, but was definately not hurting my viewing experience.

I give this movie 9 out of 10

title: Awesome rework
review:
First off, you should know that this is not a remake of the original movie, this is a rework. What is the difference? Remake is just that, a scene by scene copy of the original with a few new elements thrown in. A rework takes the basic concepts and elements from the original and gives you a whole new movie.

Now that we said that, the movie was AWESOME. Personally I think it was 10 fold better than what Romero put out in 1978. The zombies were better looking, scarier than the original, waaaaay faster and more intelligent. Which in my opinion would be exactly what a freshly dead person would act like.

The acting was good. Rahmes did a great job, a real bad ass in the movie. Polly's performance was outstanding. She has some reals bug balls in this film and quick thinking (like remembering to grab the keys). The others performances were on par, I will admit, however that Pfier's acting abiliy was wasted. The role he got sucked big time. I wish they could have written in a better character for him.

There wasn't ANY Romero type gore in the movie. The movie had more supence and close calls than anything else and relied heavily on that. There is alot of blood and some great kills, but nothing I think anyone hasn't seen before.

I'm not going to tell you anything that happens the film other than saying that you should stay through the whole ending credits. :)

Rating 8

title: The Two Films Balance One Another Out
review:
When I first heard of this remake, I shook my fists at the heavens and spat defiantly on the ground...cursing Hollywood for making such travesty. However, I saw the trailers and thought I'd give it a try. Surprisingly, I was not disappointed with this remake. It was fast, vicious, and gruesome; Not what I thought it would be (a mindless teenybopper piece of garbage with talentless, pretty people). However, it did lack the the key narrative points that made the original so great. There were too many characters and, as a result, they did not develop into characters that warranted sympathy. Except for Ving Rhames and Sarah Polly, the rest of the cast were dull and annoying, I was happy when they ended up zombie fodder (I especially wanted the kid from Air Bud to be zombie-fied, but disappointingly it did not happen). The mall became a secondary backdrop. The original's mall became a character itself, becoming part of the people inside. While the outside world was going to hell, they had a safe, secure home. Lastly, the entire idea of consumerism equaling mindless zombies was ignored. The good points about the remake: incrediblezombie effects, they were hideous and terrifying; the tense action sequences; the cameos by the cast of the original, the store in the mall named Gaylen Ross; the questionable and

unnerving ending; and some (only just some) of the changes to the story (the zombie infestation happening so quickly, only the bites causing resurrection,etc). In sum, this was not a bad remake. What it lacked, the original had...and what the original lacked, the remake had.

I give this movie an 8 because it scared the crap out of me. I should mention here that I have a special sort of fear for zombie movies. I really don't know why.

I liked it a lot. I do have complaints but they are only based on my "RUN, RUN, DAMN YOU!!!! RUUUUUUUN!" ideas that go through my head during such a movie (in other words, cliche things that have run themselves out.....).

Other than that, it was pretty cool.

I am going to have nightmares. Ugh. If you dig that whole "zombie" movie thing, this is a fun flick to see. If you are like me, though, and see these only to torture yourself with fear.....well, heck, I guess it is still fun. hahaha.

I think horror movie types should see it. Seriously. Good scares, good actors, good makeup, great ending.

Cheers!

title: REMAKES RULE GENRE TERRITORY!
review: I have to tell you after watching the stupid teaser for this film my expectations weren't very high. And although the trailer kicked major ass I still had doubts on wheather it would even be a mediocre film, it didn't have much going for it. A brand new commerical director, a big studio, a remake of a (in my opinion) passable flaky classic.  And even after meeting the cast at the Fango Convention in January, I got a little amped to see it but still had my doubts. All of those doubts have been put to rest today. Following the same logic as The Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake this is more of a reimagining borrowing the basic ideas and updating for our times. Dawn of the Dead isn't just a good film, it's a great one. And a landmark genre picture at that. It follows the basic setup of the strangers meeting at a local mall, where they fend off hordes of zombies while trying to indulge themselves in an acceptable lifestyle. Only for the horrors of the world surrounding them to come crashing in. And boy do they do. The film boasts some of the most imaginative death sequences seen in a while and captures the overall dread and horror brought forth by the source material. Unlike it's simplistic and over hyped predecessor this film remains entertaining while staying respectful, clever and scary. It also helps that the film is fueled by taut direction, good performances especially from new horror heroine Sarah Polley and believable charachter growth and story development. The effects are also over the top, grotesque and very creative.  However the only way the film falls short is in the way that it doesn't match Chainsaw's story telling or overall intensity. But this film is definatly a new horror classic, the new generation can embrace and the old genration can treasure. One thats respectful to a genre fan's needs and yet can overcome critical stabs and remain succesful. Dawn of the Dead is just another example of how Remakes are beginning to rule genre territory and new flicks are just seemingly falling flat. Their are many reasons to cherish this film cinematograoghy, hilarious soundtrack choices, an intensly scary tone, great spfx, good story, believable performances, expert direction but the one main reason to go see it is that it's worth your money.

title: Scary scary film
review: Wow I went to see this at a special preview last night and it realy scared me and believe me ive seen a lot of horror movies. As a fan of the original movie I was expecting a soso remake with a few chills along the vein of resident evil. But what I didnt expect was to be jumping out of my skin at every sound and peeking through my fingers every 5 mins ,you may think im just a wimp but honestly it takes a lot to scare me and this is one of the only films that has managed to do so in a while, the other being Dark Water which i also recommend. I do feel  I need to say that I dont realy think that this should be classed as a remake as its very different from the original the mall is there but thats about it, its also closer in tone to something like 28 days later. I think that its not lacking when you compare it to the original because its different, where the original to me had an epic feel that was chilling as you realy felt that the problem was not just contained to the people in the mall, this movie was more action led and I felt that it focoused more on the characters we saw I didnt feel that there was a world outside that was ravaged by zombies. I also thought that a few of the characters in the remake were just there for fodder and had no real purpose as they were not developed. Those niggles aside I loved this movie and was pleasently suprised it shows films like Resident Evil (which I thought was ok when I first saw it) for the poor imitations they realy are, although dont take my word for it go see it for yourself and be afraid.

title: I had high hopes.....Spoilers
review:
well, where to start. went to see this film last night. All I have to say is some parts were funny and some were scary. I would not recommend George Romeo EVER seeing this though. There was NO character development except for Ving Rhames. the zombies were fast and scary but this really reminded me of 28 days.....just with actually dead people coming back to life.

Oh and the start, some cheesy screensaver I can recreate on my computer with the word, "Strike". Come on, is this referring to the zombies or to maybe a terrorist "strike" that caused this. the more I write the more I am thinking about this movie.

Best part was celebrity target practice. Burt Reynolds, Jay Leno. bwahahaha. funny stuff. That part was classic I must admit.

Oh, and then the part where the girl goes to get the dog. Why didnt she just whistle to get the dog back? I MEAN COME ON PEOPLE?! Then poor Andy never gets to eat his sandwich. Him and Kenneth are the only people I was really rooting for in the movie. We need George Romero to the rescue QUICK?!

Well, that is all I have to say about the movie, oh, and one last note. If you see a zombie in a fishing boat when you are going to an island I would've stay cleared of the island. No questions asked. and then we get the ending. not a happy one but could've showed it without all the camera jumping like Blair Witch and stuff and especially not cutting in and out of the credits. Very annoying. Very unoriginal.

Please email me back if you'd like to discuss the movie. At least I have Hellboy to look forward to April 2nd. Goes to show anyone can make a movie these days. I am quite saddened.
